when the developer fails to consider all of the paths associated with a pointer.
The reviewer who discovered the bug also provided a patch to fix it.

Based on the report of CVE-2016-1639, there is a Use after Free vulnerability in the WebRTC Audio Private API implementation in Google Chrome.

Use after Free is a memory problem where the memory is referenced after it is freed. Developers usually face this problem in many application where
they have to allocate memory and the previoused memory was freeed. It may cause the program to crash or use unexpected value to perform a certain action. 

The Use after Free vulnerability is dicovered in the file webrtc_audio_private_api.cc with the path browser/extensions/api/webrtc_audio_private/webrtc_audio_private_api.cc
in the WebRTC API. The vulnerability may cause denial of service or unexpect result by dependent on resource context pointer.
In the Blink Layouter, heap memory was used after being freed. This could result in arbitrary code execution or data corruption.

Before 50.0.2661.75, a denial of service / use-after-free vulnerability exists 
in Google Chrome where a crafted extension can be used to create an infinite 
amount of new hidden windows that each have an observer tied to it that is
not deleted on frame removal

There was a problem in the library where attackers could cause a DoS attack 
where an input would cause an overflow error and crash the service. The function
would try to assert that the index specified is actually within the bounds of the array.
However, before the fix, the assert that would throw an error if the index was out of range
would only throw an error in debug mode. The fix caused the error to be thrown in debug or
production mode.

When navigating from a new document to an empty document using Google's
*Blink* engine, the engine loaded the request without checking whether
navigation was allowed. Due to this, it was possible to execute an XSS attack
via the request, bypassing the browser's protections.

Remote attackers were able to bypass the "Same Origin Policy" in verions before 51.0.2704.63. The "Same Origin Policy" refers to a critical security mechanism that restricts how a document or script loaded from one origin can interact with a resource from another origin. They did so in the extensions subsystem by using a malicious extension. This allowed them to access potential sensitive information and to execute arbitrary code.

The ToV8Value function has unneccessary calls of setter functions that may
crash the Google Chrome Web Browser: This is due to a lack of necessary
restrictions on these getter and setter functions in the ToV8Value function.
The ToV8Value should never call setter functions. This behavior was
unneccessary to execute its intended purpose. This flaw can be manipulated
to trigger a use-after-free, and crash google chrome (Denial of Service).

Checks to verify the content security policy (CSP) of a request were missing
from a function that registers service workers. This allowed attackers to
bypass CSP and register service workers even if they shouldn't have been
able to.

A specific function in a PDF renderer which didn't properly handle a failure
during its initialization causes a denial of service (out-of-bounds read) via
a crafted PDF document that contained a malformed JPG image. An attacker who
knows this exploit could potentiallycause the function to halt or crash,
meaning the browser utilizing this  function may have issues resulting from
this problem.

A user could set an input value (any text box that will utilize the auto fill feature) that could cause the form being viewed to be deleted. This would then cause the data from the autofill to be deleted as well. After all this data has been deleted there could still be process running and trying to use the deleted data from the auto fill which results in a crash.

When downloading a style sheet, the checks on the style sheet were
insufficient. An actor could carefully craft a style sheet such that they
could inject scripting that could not only be executed, but it could have
access to native functions. This could lead to the attacker executing their
own scripting with the native functions.

Attackers were able to create javascript code that would escape from a html
specific html element known as an iframe, allowing them access a different 
page from an untrusted origin and execute javascript code on the target page.

Lack of proper distrustful decomposite design led to the inclusion of a bug, which allowed a client script access to read the contents of a computer's entire filesystem.
By design, Chrome DevTools are allowed to run unsafe-eval, and unsafe-inline javascript execution. This shouldn't be an issue, because all trusted dev tools should be hosted at chrome-devtools-frontend.appspot.com/. This url is whitelisted, and only JavaScript code the browser believes came from this source is allowed to run with these typed of permissions. This security model allows DevTools to have more power and freedom than the average web page should be allowed to have, with reasonably little attack surface for exploit vectors to enter through. The omission of proper sanitization of the src attribute attatched to iFrame elements in a page, however, exposed an elevation of privlages vulnerability by executing code that may or may not come from the whitelisted source.

During the creation of an array of views for an extension, there is
nothing that prevents setters from destroying a view in one of the array
indeces, which triggers unexpected behavior when said destroyed view is
attempted to be accessed by other parts of the extension and browser.

The Chrome web store inine-installation implementation in the extensions subsystem does not properly consider object lifetimes during progress observation. This allows for remote attacks to cause a denial of service. Modifications of some system files or information is possible, but the attacker does not have direct control of what can be modified.

An architectural problem existed in the way Chromium deferred the loading of 
pages.  This problem involved pages created by frames on pages that had been
deferred not also being deferred.  This made it possible for an attacker to
craft and transfer a frame across the deferral boundary (between different
pages), essentially allowing them to inject malicious code across origins 
(sources of data).  This violates the Same-origin Policy.
The ability to determine if an anonymous block wrapper existing did not work properly.  This caused a vulnerability that could allow remote attackers to cause a denial of service.

The Content Security Policy (CSP) implementation in Blink, as used in Google Chrome before 49.0.2623.75, does not ignore a URLs path component in the case of a ServiceWorker fetch, which allows remote attackers to obtain sensitive information about visited web pages by reading CSP violation reports, related to FrameFetchContext.cpp and ResourceFetcher.cpp.

This was a vulnerability that allowed remote attackers to attack Google Chrome 
before version 52.0.2743.82 had been released. Remote attackers can cause a 
denial of service or possibly other problems that are not specified. 

The attacks can be done using JavaScript code. The code involves @import 
at-rule in a CSS token sequence along with a rel=import attribute of a 
LINK element. This just means that the attacker is able to attack the HTML
file while the user is trying to import a file. This seems similar to the 
Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) vulnerability we discussed in class.

The vulnerabilitywas caused by the implementation of a function that handled the range-to
function in XML. There was code where after memory was freed, it was attempted to be used
which can cause Chrome to crash or freeze. This could be abused to intentionally make Chrome
unavailable to users or allow for remote code execution.

This vulnerability comes from lack of foresight during initial development,
or a misunderstanding of how the process is being used. This vulnerability 
is effectively a way for an attacker to mislead users and obtain their
credentials.

The Proxy Auto-Config (PAC) feature in Google Chrome does not ensure that the
URL information is restricted to the schema, host and port. This allows remote
attackers to discover credentials by operating a server with a PAC script.

Referencing memory after it has been freed can lead to a variety of behaviors including crashing and corrupting data. 

In this specific CVE, when an extension is loaded or unloaded by the application, the content
of these scripts are unregistered. If this happens in the middle of an injection, the freed addresses
of these unregistered scripts are accessed causing a use after free vulnerability causing a crash.

WebKit's schemeMatches function in the Content Security Policy does not apply
http port 80 policies to https port 443 URLs and does not apply WebSocket (ws) 
port 80 policies to WebSocketSecure (wss) port 443 URLs. 

A Content Security Policy is a security measure that can be added to a site 
to restrict what resources can be loaded in the browser. When the
schemeMatches function does not treat image resources identically through 
each protocol, an attacker can set a Content Security Policy that restricts
images from http and ws protocols. When an attacker does this they can monitor
the response time for the resources and determine if the user has visited 
the image's domain previously (if the response time is quick, then the image
is cached). This is sniffing browser history.

A heap buffer overflow vulnerability is present in the jpeg2000. In this vulnerability
memory that is dynamically allocated has been been used passed its bounds.

There is a vulnerability with Chrome DevTools. Previously, when a url was 
passed in to a function and the function attempted to sanitize the url,
the sanitization algorithm was insufficient. This allowed attackers to bypass
access restrictions and inject arbitrary HTML tags into the page. The bug allowed
chrome extensions such as Google Tone to be used to execute Cross-Site Scripting attacks
through the 'chrome-devtool://' URLs.
CVE-2016-5147, or known as Blink, is an attack that uses deferred page loadings to inject web scripts or malicious HTML.

Properties are variable attributes of an object. Like color is a property for
for a Bird. Properties can also be inherented from their perent class. 
For example, Bird can inheret properties from the Animal parent class.


Key-paths are a way of storing uninvoked references to properties.
This means they refer to a property itself rather than to that property’s value. 

The vulnerability was in Google's Javascript Engine, *V8*, in an API 
implementation written in C. Getters using key-paths were
not restricted to inherited properties, allowing getters on prototypes
to be executed. 

This created a use-after-free vulnerability. Use After Free specifically refers to the 
attempt to access memory after it has been freed, which can cause a program to crash
in the best case. 
Worst case, since this is a vulnerability in a JavaScript feature, attackers could 
execute arbitrary code or even enable full remote code execution capabilities.

Certain early builds of the software PDFium for chrome mishandles
timers, allowing remote attackers to cause a denial-of-service by trying to reference
memory that has already been freed by the system. That or some other unspecified

The C++ event binder would fail to add an event matcher to a list
of filtered events. After failing, the events would still be processed and
the missing event would never be run. If the missing event was followed up
with another event that required memory to be freed by the previous event, the
next event in the sequence would never be run. The event now waiting for
memory to be freed would cause a denial of service as it is just sitting
there waiting indefinitely.

In two places int overflows can occur, PDFium and OpenJPEG. The int overflow can be targeted to cause a denial of service this is done thorough a heap-based buffer overflow. Also this could have unspecified impact on JPEG data

The vulnerability was in Chrome's extensions utility. Every extension has
a manifest.json file, which holds a 'web_accessible_resources' field.
This field states every internal resource of the extension that can be accessed via
the web.
The system would allow a user to open an iframe to the settings page of the extension. Attackers could use this vulnerability to trick users into changing the settings of extensions.

While English and many other languages are processed from left-to-right (LTR), other languages (like Arabic and Hebrew) are processed from right-to-left (RTL).  Unicode supports characters from both classifications.  Strings made up of both LTR and RTL characters must be displayed in a specific order using the bidirectional text (bidi) algorithm.
In this vulnerability, on Chrome for Android, when a user entered a URL into the address bar, if the first strong character (A character with a clear direction, either LTR or RTL.  Usually an alphabetic character) in the URL is RTL, an attacker could construct a URL that was displayed in reverse, introducing address bar spoofing by constructing URLs that appear to be visiting one domain but are actually visiting some malicious site.
For example, in the URL 127.0.0.1/ا/http://example.com , the first strong character from LTR is ا.  This character causes the neutral characters (numbers and punctuation) preceding it to take on the RTL direction, while http://example.com remains LTR.  As a result, the URL is displayed as http://example.com/‭ا/127.0.0.1, with the LTR segment appearing before the RTL segment.
The displayed URL is an example of address bar spoofing because it leads the user to believe they are visiting example.com, when they are actually navigating to localhost.  This vulnerability was found in Omnibox, which is responsible for things like URL auto-complete, instant search, and search suggestions.

The reciever of an IPC message was never validated, meaning the messages could
be sent out to null, invalid or 'dead' processes. This created an opportunity
for denial of service attacks as well as an opening for arbitrary code execution.

it is possible to trigger an integer overflow in xsltAddTextString in

Use after free in ANGLE.

Out of bounds write in PDFium. Chrome Browser is vulnerable to Out of Bound

Incorrect handling of cookies in Cast. When a user starts the browser, it
immediately sends a UDP multicast SSDP request to 239.255.255.250:1900. The

requests, all without any user interaction or awareness.

Cross-origin bypass in Blink. By setting up a header of "X-XSS-Protection: 1;
report=cross-domain-uri" it is possible to send cross-origin post request with
content-type value of "application/json". Any request containing content-type
of "application/json" should trigger a pre-flight request - but this is not
happening. Imagine a situation where an application isn't expecting any
parameters for an endpoint of https://app.com/user/1000/delete for a POST
request and the only CSRF-Protection is based on CORS - this would bypass this
restriction.
Type confusion in V8. This problem is related to the crankshaft JIT.
Out of bounds read in V8.

Address spoofing in Omnibox. The URL bar is the only reliable security
indicator in browsers and if the only reliable security indicator could be
controlled by an attacker it could carry adverse affects. For instance
potentially tricking users into supplying sensitive information to a malicious
website due to the fact that it could easily lead the users to believe that
they are visiting is legitimate website as the address bar points to the
correct website.
Use after free in print preview.
Embargoed. Use after free in Apps Bluetooth.

Information leak in CSP reporting. Adding a Content-Security-Policy header
containing a report-uri can lead to the leak of the current URL fragment to
the web server, even though it should never be sent. This turns an otherwise
active attack (serving an evil JavaScript file to the user to make it leak the
fragment) into a passive and deferred attack, using a mechanism otherwise made
to improve the security.
Address spoofing in Omnibox. "Canadian Syllabics" unicode breaks URLs.
Heap buffer overflow in Skia.
Possible command injection in mailto handling.

UI spoofing in Blink. Usually, window.open() deactivates the origin window
and validation bubble on the origin window is closed. However, if
window.print() is executed, it suspends message loop of the window, and
deactivation isn't noticed until print dialog is closed.

Use after free in credit card autofill. Duplicate instances of SaveCardBubble
fail to get cleaned up.

Extension verification bypass. There is an approach to bypass extension's
content verification mechanism in Chromium-based browsers. This approach is
used by malware / adware writers and there are malicious extensions droppers,
which use this mechanism ITW. The nutshell of the bug is a lack of
verification in extensions locale folder. So, it's possible to create
extension, which consists of only content script, for example, and this
script is located in _locales folder.
UI spoofing in Blink.
Local access to local files via dbus.

Inappropriate javascript execution on WebUI pages. From a security POV this
doesn't seem terribly interesting (the attacker must convince the user to add
a dangerous bookmarklet, navigate to a privileged page, and invoke the
bookmarklet).
Address spoofing in Omnibox.

Sandbox Escape in IndexedDB. When an IndexedDB transaction is created,
indexed_db_connection.cc stores a map from transaction id to a unique_ptr
containing the IndexedDBTransaction, and schedules some actions with the raw
pointer. A compromised renderer can create a new transaction with the same
id, leading to UaF when one of the raw pointers is accessed.

Out of bounds read in V8: v8::wasm::module-decoder. This discloses sensitive
information in the heap.

Domain spoofing in Omnibox. The character "U+0F8C" when used in a domain name
in Chrome looks just like a space. This can be abused to spoof a legitimate
domain followed by a chain of the character. This is a Mac OS-specific
vulnerability.

Use after free in IndexedDB. In normal scenarios, a cursor is created and
passed off to a callback function, however, if there are no callbacks, the
cursor gets destructed, but the pointer to it remains within the system.

Use after free in PPAPI. The sandbox process sends an IPC message to the
browser, but the browser is unable to verify its authenticity. This results
in the browser reading uninitialized memory from the heap and crashing.
Embargoed. Type confusion in extensions.
Out-of-bounds write in PDFium.

User information leak via Android intents. URL can be used to navigate from
HTTP to FILE.
(i.e. "googlechrome://navigate?url=file:///sdcard/Download/a.html")
Out-of-bounds read in Skia.
Use after free in V8.

Out-of-bounds write in PPAPI. When the sandbox process fails to verify the
authenticity of a message, fake data can be inserted, resulting in elevation
of privilege.
Use after free in Chrome Apps.

URL spoofing in OmniBox. By changing the location hash and calling a modal
dialog at the same time a user focuses on the omnibox it's possible to spoof
the URL and the HTTPS lock. After the spoof, if the user tries to interact
with the webpage the URL will return to normal, but this can be circumvented
by putting the user in fullscreen after his first click.

Uninitialized use in Skia. Uninitialized value was created by an allocation
of "color" in the stack frame of the "ReadBuffer" function.

Uninitialized use in Skia. Uninitialized value was created by an allocation
of "src" in the stack frame of the "ReadBuffer" function.

UI spoofing in browser. Secure/Not Secure label next to URL could be spoofed
on Mac OS.

URL spoofing in OmniBox. Spoofing occurs when inserting "U+0650" into
the URL.

URL spoofing in OmniBox. Similar to CVE-2017-5105, spoofing occurs when
inserting Cyrillic characters into a URL.
Type confusion in PDFium.

UI spoofing in payments dialog. PaymentRequestAPI shows the native payment UI.
An attacker can change the origin of payment from this screen. Basically, you can
spoof the payment screen so that it changes where the payment screen comes from.
This allows an abuser to use the spoofing to change the what is being paid out and to where.
Embargoed. Use after free in PDFium.
Embargoed. Heap buffer overflow in WebGL.
Embargoed. Heap buffer overflow in Skia.
Embargoed. Memory lifecycle issue in PDFium.
Embargoed. Type confusion in V8.
Embargoed. Type confusion in V8.
Embargoed. Use of uninitialized value in Skia.
Embargoed. Bypass of Content Security Policy in Blink.
Embargoed. Use of uninitialized value in Skia.
Embargoed. Potential HTTPS downgrade during redirect navigation.
Embargoed. Out-of-bounds access in V8.
Embargoed. Out-of-bounds access in V8.
Embargoed. UXSS with MHTML.
Embargoed. Heap overflow in Skia.
Embargoed. Use after free in PDFium.
Embargoed. Use after free in PDFium.
Embargoed. Heap overflow in WebGL.
Embargoed. Use after free in WebAudio.
Embargoed. Heap overflow in libxml2.
Embargoed. Out of bounds write in Skia.
Embargoed. Incorrect stack manipulation in WebAssembly.
Embargoed. Out of bounds write in Skia.
Embargoed. Pointer disclosure in SQLite.

BroadPwn security bug. A bug in Broadcom's WIFI chipsets allows remote access
to billions of Android and iOS phones.

An error related to handling URLs containg a "chromehtml: protocol" could allow
an attacker to run malicious scripts or search files on the local disk. Visiting
an attacker-controlled web page in Internet Explorer could launch Google Chrome,
open multiple tabs, and load scripts that run after navigating to a URL of the
attacker's choice. This argument injection vulnerabilty allows for universal cross-site
scripting.

This vulnerability was a heap-based buffer overflow accessible via Google Chrome's IPC messaging. 
This could allow attackers to malicously access the Bitmap Renderer and cause a denial of service (application crash) 
or possibly execute arbitrary code via vectors related to a large bitmap that arrived over the IPC channel. This means that 
arbitrary data inputs were not properly verified and sanitized when data was passed to the Renderer. This overflow could allow 
for arbitrary execution meaning the attacker could control the system and perform more advanced attacks once they know what inputs
are controlled by the user and how the system handles input data.

This vulnerability would only be accessible after an attacker has gained control of the system and jumped here from another 
previously discovered vulnerability. This is due to the subsystem not being customer-facing, and no actual user input is passed here.
The attacker would have to exploit other inputs to the system to utilize this heap overflow, due to IPC messages.

Cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerability in Google Chrome 2.x and 3.x before 3.0.195.21 
allows remote attackers to inject arbitrary web script or HTML via a (1) RSS or (2) Atom feed, 
related to the rendering of the application/rss+xml content type as XML "active content."

This vulnerability can be described as a buffer overread, in which an
attacker can force an array index to read beyond the bounds of the array.
An attacker can use this to induce a system crash or to potentially read
memory they shouldn't have access to.
This vulnerability occurs in chromium's bitmap buffers. The bitmap buffer
itself and the row size of the bitmap buffer are given
by two different sources which can fall out of sync, causing the bitmap
reader to read beyond the contents of the actual buffer (e.g. if the given
buffer is small).

Attackers are able to traverse local google files by using vectors related to
"developer tools" in the Chromium Browser.

This was an error that caused chromes memory to become corrupted. The issue would occurr when a user attempted to connecto to a site that was marked for malware that no longer existed, clicked continue anyway and then refreshed the page during the long loading time. This would cause memory corruption that could be used to execute code outside of the original memory space.

This vulnerability allows remote attackers to bypass the whitelist of
acceptable plugins. The whitelist is part of the host-based settings. The 
whitelist works as intended when navigating, because all webpages will have a
host. The issue is when a new tab is first created, there is no host and thus
the plugin whitelist will not be applied.  

The fix for this vulnerability was having new windows inherit host-based settings
from the parent.

There are certain objects that are read in through the DispatchObject()
function as clipboard objects. One of the types of objects that could be
read through this function, CBF_SMBITMAP to be exact, contains information
that points to a shared memory object. If someone who normally does not have
access to the shared memory object obtains access, they could potentially
modify the object which may affect other processes using it. This dangerous
process is normally okay since there are other methods that make it secure.
However, there was a particular instance where said methods were not used,
resulting in an unsecure use of the CBF_SMBITMAP object.

This vulnerability pertains to the availability of the browser. If it was
exploited, the chromium web browser would crash. Websites can create and allow 
the user to view Javascript dialogs. These dialogs can be queued so that another 
may pop up when one closes. The crash would occur when a dialog that is in the queue 
closes. In order to do this, multiple tabs must be opened in the browser. If both
pages open a dialog simultaniously it would trigger the vulnerability.

The security information dialog in Chrome incorrectly displayed the hostname.
In Windows, the hostname became merged with the following line and in Linux
it was truncated. This could potentially result in an attacker using a long
hostname to spoof another website.

A workaround was created for a Windows kernel bug that was triggered by hinting malformed fonts. Hinting is the process of rasterizing the vector fonts into bitmaps for specific display resolutions and is only applicable with the Compact Font Format (CFF) since raster information is stored in the TTF format.
Versions of Chrome prior to 5.0.375.127 do not properly implement file dialogs, allowing attackers to cause denial of service attacks.

Google Chrome before 6.0.472.59 on Linux did not properly handle cursors, which might have allowed attackers to cause a denial of service (assertion failure) via unspecified vectors.

For example, if a user were to login to my.safaribooks, click on a link to a book and move the mouse around, the user should still be able to move the mouse around and continue to use chrome. However, what happens instead is a fatal assertion failure with a message of the backtrace.

An invalid memory access flaw was found in libxml2, a library providing
support to read, modify and write XML and HTML files. A remote attacker could
provide a specially crafted XML file that, when processed by an application using libxml2,
would lead to an read at an invalid memory address, causing an application
crash (denial of service).
 read XPath expressions (a method used to navigate through elements and
attributes in an XML file), an attacker could craft an XML document with
malformed XPaths that would cause an application crash.

This is due to the way libxml2 reads XPath expressions, which are a method t navigate
through elements of an XML file. As libxml2 parses XML, it creates "contexts" (looks
to be similar concept as scope) as it goes through the tree structure. The XPath most likely
cause a reference to an invalid or null context, resulting in an invalid memory access.

This could be done by creating an XML file that forces the parser to attempt to
read from an invalid memory location, leading to a crash. This is the example
given by the reporter of the vulnerability.
Does not handle form input in a safe manner allowing attackers to crash the application (DoS) due to a stale pointer bug, a programming error during dynamic memory allocation.

The vulnerability was in Google Chrome where they did not check the data type
of an event object returned from a page click.

The implementation, which was done in C++, didn't properly check if the event
object it got back was a mouse event before executing it.  This could result
in a crash or other unexpected events.

The way this could be exploited would be if an attacker found out about this
vulnerability and used it to purposely crash the site.  This could prevent
other people from accessing the site, also known as denial of service.

The vulnerability is such that Chrome is able to open a webpage as a pop-up, which can be abused as malicious users will generate unwanted pages by bypassing the pop-up blocker using cross site-scripting (and by extension, cross-origin scripting). Chrome did not check whether the input was generated by an actual user. It is basically an example of improper input validation.

Before 8.0.552.215, Google Chrome has a vulnerability that allows an attacker 
to create an infinite amount of file dialogs that can crash the browser by 
consuming all available memory. This vulnerability was proven to be present
through a crafted extension

There is a double free vulnerability in libxml2 2.7.8 and other version as used in gogole chrome before 8.0.552.215.
The vulnerability allows one to pop an XPath object off the stack, and since the object won't be null, it can be popped again.
Double free vulnerability is a common memory corruption error when developers free the same memory location twice by calling free() on the same
 allocated memory. 

 This vulnerability may allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service or possibly have unspecified other impact relate to the Xpath in this case.

This issue was reported on Oct. 5 2010 by chromium user 'Eroman', and fixed by
user 'johnnyg' on Dec. 1 2010

from the chromium Notifications subsystem

Google chrome did not properly handle an extensions notifications, thus allowing
remote attackers to cause the application to crash (denial of service) through the
use of unspecified vectors.

Google Chrome before 8.0.552.237 and Chrome OS before 8.0.552.344 do not properly handle a mismatch in video frame sizes, which allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service (incorrect memory access) or possibly have unspecified other impact via unknown vectors.

Faulty logic for checking volume of audio caused the browser to crash, with
potential for a large scale attack.

A function meant to handle javascript dialog cleanup was not
properly implemented and would lead to site crash. This meant
that an attacker had the means to invoke a site crash or
denial of service attack. The vulnerability also left the application
open to arbitrary code execution though no instances were reported.

The WebGL implementation in Google Chrome allowed remote attackers to cause a 
denial of service (out-of-bounds read) via unspecified vectors.  This means that the
application was not verifying the inputs to the system properly and an attacker could
have utilized this vulnerability to crash the application, or perform more advanced exploits.

This vulnerability only presented itself when ran with a specific command line flag for
handling WebGL versions and the system had certain checks that were not performed
When this flag was set.

CVE-2011-1122 allows attempts to read memory outside expected
boundaries on the host operating system. This vulnerability specifically
exploits mistakes in how vectors were handled. Specifically, it would
use an integer overflow to force an out of bounds memory read from the
webkit engine.

It is a denial of service exploit as this would typically cause the operating
system to terminate the application.

It was fixed by preventing certain vector attributes from getting used with
OpenGL ES 2.0.

This vulnerability present in Google Chrome's video feature could cause a denial of service attack because it allowed remote attackers to execute arbitrary code causing an "out-of-bounds" error and crashing the system.This is due to code that miscounts thread numbers.

This vulnerability is related to incomplete sandboxing around the chrome
renderer process and chrome extensions. By tracing process ids and messages
it would be possible for an attacker to spoof parts of chrome and execute
arbitrary code.

The vulnerability did not effect Windows, but on Linux it was possible for
attackers to escape their sandbox and install their own extensions remotely.
This is Linux specific because on Linux it was possible for sandboxed processes
to interfere with each other due to requirements for chrome's crash reporting
system, breakpad. 

It is unclear in the chrome bug reporting whether the vector of attack was
directly through breakpad, but the interprocess communication with breakpad
allows for improper information disclosure of process IDs. This is what
exposes the system to spoofing.

Heap-based buffer overflow in Google Chrome's blob URL handling code. 
The vulnerability allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code via 
unspecified vectors that trigger an out-of-bounds write.

The fix for this vulnerability is to free memory as the very last step in the
affected function.
The Accessibility UI attempts to use memory after it's been freed. This allows for exploitable memory corruption, denial of service, or other impact via unknown attack vectors.
Having a large number of forms on a webpage would cause the browser to crash.

Chrome before 12.0.742.91 allows remote attackers to bypass intended access
restictions through certain extensions. The tabs permissions defined in the
manifest file of Chrome extensions could be bypassed if a webpage was spoofed.
Universal Cross Site Scripting exploit possible when abusing window.execScript.

The drag-and-drop implementation in Google Chrome on Linux does not properly
enforce permissions for files. This allows attackers to create a file link on their 
website (e.x. <a href="file:///etc/passwd">) and if the user drags this link onto something
like a file upload, and it will upload the file from the users device.

Failing to lock and unlock the GPU allows for reentrancy issues allowing
remote attackers to execute a denial of service attack, crashing the application
using unspecified vectors.

Google was using the libxml2 library for Chrome. The way they were using the
library allowed attackers to cause a double free by entering certain types
of code in a query. A double free can result in memory being changed that
you did not anticipate, which can result in a Denial of Service attack.
Additionally the memory that was freed twice can also cause malloc to get
called on it twice, resulting in a pointer being returned to the same
location in memory for two different malloc calls. This could also allow for
a buffer overflow attack.

The cache has a race condition when being used by the X507 certificate. It was a very difficult problem,
as it would probably need some significant changes to one or more of the already existing APIs in use.

Google Chrome had a Linux specific bug based in compiler options. The compiler
was not configured to use the PIC (Position Independent Code) and PIE
(Position Independent Executable). Since the code wasn't being compiled as 
expected, the attack surface was unpredictable.

The most plausible security attack here could have been related to denial of
service on certain machines due to compilitation related crashes. Because there is
memory positioning involved with the vulnerability, information disclosure could
also be an issue in the case of an overflow.

The chrome team's conversation didn't seem very concerned with the details of
possible attacks here, and the security severity of the bug was low. Security-wise
this seemed like a "better safe than sorry" situation.

Video conversion and transformations were not being properly handled, which
could allow remote attackers to cause a denial of service.

This vulnerability was the result of accessing an array at x-1 when x == 0.

Javascript used by Chrome to translate web pages is downloaded over HTTP. This script is executed in the context of the web page to be translated.
translate/translate_manager.cc in Google Chrome before 17.0.963.56 and 19.x before 19.0.1036.7 uses an HTTP session to exchange data for translation, which allows remote attackers to obtain sensitive information by sniffing the network.

When a function is called to expand the size of a PNG (within Google Chrome),
the value associated with the size of the PNG can be as large as requested
(meaning there is no size limitation). The reason it can be so arbitrarily
large is because in the process of inflating a compressed image holds the need
to "throw away" chunks of data if (when they are decompressed) have an output
arguement of 0. Due to this vulnerability, malicious users can exploit this
and create a value for the data that when expanded is greater than the type
value (png_size_t) can hold causing an overflow. This obviously leads to
memory allocation issues and heap-buffer-overflow. It is a possible entry
point for malicious attackers to implement a DoS or possibly have unspecified
other impact(s) by tampering with integers via truncation.

Inter-process Communication implementation does not correctly validate
messages allowing for attack vectors. It is possible to create a fake
listener process that does not have the proper permissions to connect to
a pipe started by the browser's process and cause a privledge escalation.

The vulnerability allowed remote attackers to intentionally cause an
application crash by means of a specialized web page.

If an attacker placed an FTP URL in the SRC attribute of an HTML
<video> tag, then a browser crash would inevitably result when a user
visited the web page and loaded the video.

This was caused by a failure to properly create FtpTransaction objects for
media delivered over FTP. The FtpTransaction object handles FTP transactions
between the web page and client. While the majority of non-media content
delivered over FTP used an FtpTransactionFactory object to create
transactions, any media content, like videos, delivered over FTP didn't
use the FtpTransactionFactory, which resulted in a NULL pointer dereference
and a subsequent application crash when used.

While the original reporter only noticed this issue when the FTP URL was
within a <video> tag, the application would have similarly crashed if the user
had placed an FTP URL ending in a media file format (AVI, MP3, etc.) in
Chrome's address bar and hit enter. This was also the case for malformed
FTP URLs with no file extension.

The input validation vulnerability did not properly handle Tibetan text, and thus an
out-of-bounds read could occur during Tibetan handling. If a Tibetan letter was followed
by a Tibetan cantillation sign, a global buffer overflow would be reported.

The vulnerability was located in the method called tibetan_form().

This vulnerability could be exploited by remote attackers, who could execute arbitrary
code on the system and cause a denial of service via the out-of-bounds read through
the use of unspecified vectors. They can accomplish this by persuading a victim to
visit a specially-crafted web site or JavaScript program using Chromium or V8, where
they could exploit the vulnerability to trigger the out-of-bounds read in order to
execute the arbitrary code on the system.
Google Chrome does not properly handle drag and drop operations on URL strings, which allows user-assisted remote attackers to spoof the URL bar via unspecified vectors.

A timing issues in the DOM traversal can cause denial of service attacks and
remote vector issues or possible unknown issuess through a crafted document.

The DOM stands for Document Object Model and is a tree like structure, used to
represent the HTML webpage.

The DOM traversal runs for at most 50ms before pausing to allow the WebkKit 
thread to run. If the frame is removed before the traversal resumes then it
will attempt to access a deleted WebFrame.

The fix is to ensure that the WebDocument is not null.

An interesting note is that these vulnerabilities are in a client side phishing
detection model.

After a user performed a paste operation, an attacker could use malicious
code on a webpage that could start a loop that would continiuously monitor 
the user's clipboard. This could allow attackers to steal password information 
and other sensitive data from the clipboard

Google Chrome crashed when the program internally called a function.
This function tries to access data from a NULL variable. This allows remote attackers
to cause a denial of service (application crash).

In general, this is a NULL Pointer Deference problem, that can occur when the
application deferences a pointer expecting it to be a valid, but is NULL.
This causes a program to crash or exit.

Django.description:
Someone can repeatedly make logout requests, which would cause many new empty
sessions to be created. This can result in an interruption in service availability
by filling up the session store, and it can cause other users' session records to
be evicted.

There was a vulnerability in Django that caused the read-only password 
widget that was used to obfuscate passwords to not work correctly for admin
users that had 'view only' permissions for users. As a result, those users
were able to see the entirety of arbitrary users' hashed passwords. If the 
password hashes are weak, this could lead to user passwords and accounts 
being compromised.

The vulnerability was caused when the utility method strip_tags(), which 
takes any input string and removes all the html tags from it, was changed to 
work iteratively. It was possible for the size of the input the method
was processing to grow larger with each iteration, which could result in an 
infinite loop and denial of service.

For the fix, strip_tags() was changed so that it will return the original 
input if it detects the length of the string it's processing has increased.

It was discovered that Django incorrectly handled a large number of forms
when generating formsets. An attacker could use this flaw to cause Django to
consume memory, resulting in a denial of service. This has been fixed by
adding a default maximum number of forms of 1,000. Developers can still manually
specify a bigger max_num.

Django allows account takeover. A suitably crafted email address (that is equal
to an existing user's email address after case transformation of Unicode characters)
would allow an attacker to be sent a password reset token for the matched user account.
(One mitigation in the new releases is to send password reset tokens only to the
registered user email address.

Directory-traversal vulnerability on Windows
User session data is stored in a file named after the session key.
Verification was used to ensure the session key did not include a file path 
seperator. Including one could lead to file traversal when working with the 
file. Their verification was not comprehensive enough for Windows. On 
windows "\" is the normally used character, however "/" is also useable. Due 
to a failure to check for "/" on Windows, this opened a door that could be 
used by potentially more serious vulnerabilites.

This vunerabilty was that the class basehttp was creating and using url to static media files
but in the process of creating the urls was not safely joining the parts, giving attackers a chance
to craft their own urls in order to access files they normally should not have had access to.

The authentication framework in Django has a backend which authenticates
a user's username and password. When an authentication request is submitted,
the username and password are then processed to verify the user's identity.
Remote Attackers are able to cause a denial of service by sending very large
passwords to be processed. Processing these large passwords consumes a large
amount of CPU power which causes the denial of service. The fix involved
adding a limit to password length, this was then reverted and the fix ended up
being a change to how passwords are processed.

A critical vulnerability that can be initiated remotely and with no
form of authentication required for a successful exploitation, was found in Django. 
Peter Kuma and Gavin Wahl found that the django.util.http.is_safe_url function does not properly validate URLs, 
which allows remote attackers to conduct open redirect attacks via a malformed URL, 
as demonstrated by "http:\\\djangoproject.com."

Django allows you to serve static files (e.g. images, JavaScript, CSS) to a
website during development using the serve function.
Since this function reads the files it serves one line at a time, a big file
with no newlines would result in memory usage equal to the size of that file.
Therefore, an attacker could exploit this and launch a denial-of-service attack
by requesting to serve multiple large files.

A pop-up related function was made vulnerable to cross site scripting
attacks due to the fact that the inputs that were being supplied by the user were
not being sanitized properly. This allowed attackers to enter dangerous scripts
which could steal authentication credentials from the user, and even change how
the site is being rendered to the user.

The fix for this issue was referencing the content in the text instead of the content
within the HTML, this prevents the execution of the data.

The cookie parsing code in Django when used on a site with Google Analytics 
allows remote attackers to bypass CSRF protection by setting arbitrary cookies.

This Django vulnerability stems from the ability to use a property
of jQuery (a JavaScript Frontend Library) to modify internal python objects.
This, in turn, allows for information that is not supposed to be in the
class object for a python class to appear, or enables users to modify the
class object without having to directly access the code. This, at a high
level, is known as a cross-site scripting vulnerability, as you are putting
information that shouldn't exist within the application's current state,
in the application's state.

This attack is completed by modiftying the __proto__ property of a
request to the backend, which in turn would allow this new object to extend
the object that already created. This is a major issue, as cross-site
scripting can lead large data leaks, false information for users, and much
more.

Django provides tools that help accept, process, and render user inputs through
forms by handling preparing and restructuring of data for rendering, creating
HTML forms for the data, and receiving and processing submitted forms and data
from the client. Forms in Django use Widgets to handle the rendering of HTML
form input elements on the web page and extraction of raw submitted data.
This vulnerability comes from lack of sanitization for the AdminURLFieldWidget
which takes in a url string as input that is used to render a clickable link.
Without validation that the entered url is a well formatted url containing no
malicious code, an attacker can perform a Cross Site Scripting attack by inserting
a piece of code into this form field that is then executed and reflected to the user.

The vulnerability had to do with Django's storage of session data. One option 
for storing session data is to store it in the cache. When session data is 
stored in the cache, the session identifier is used as a key. This option is 
provided with Django itself.

If the session data is stored in the cache, a hacker can store arbitrary data 
using a key which is a valid session identifier. Djang will treat that data as 
session data, allowing the hacker to modify session information as long as they
know the session key.

A method called verify_exits uses a python library that calls the arbitrary URL
without a timeout. This can be a security threat as someone can cause denial of
service by simply passing a url into the verify_exists which is associated with
a slow response or a large amount of data sent.

Remote authenticated users were able to obtain information that they shouldn't have access to,
due to the lack of checking permissions. Generally, only those with administrative privileges were 
able to access the history view of UI objects, but in this case anyone could access it. The history 
view includes a series of logs, each containing a description the changes made to the object. All 
of this information was located in Django's bundled administrative interface. The vulnerability was
fixed by checking the current user's permissions, and denying access if they aren't valid for viewing
object history.

In versions 1.4.x and 1.5.x of Django, an oversight in ssi template tags granted
user inputed files unauthroized access to root directories. When reading in arbitrary
files it allowed directory traversal, potentially exposing directories containing 
sensitive information such as passwords.

The Django admin interface allowed for remote authenticated users to open up 
a popup with information on relationships between data models obtained using 
a to_field parameter. There was no check in place to verify that the field 
being used actually represented a relationship, meaning that sensitive data 
that should be hidden could be accessed in this way.

Django provided a method in an attempt to combat issues with urls to prove
they are safe, but it failed in this instance as this CVE allowed malicious
users to manipulate urls (opening up cross-site scripting vulnerabilities) via
changing the leading whitespace before the url's actual location. Once
changed, the method would fail to catch urls that were unsafe due to the
whitespace, and the url would be processed in the system.

Essentially, when the method was run with a string like "\nthiswebsite.com"
the is_safe method would return true (as accepted input). But that whitespace
could allow a bad actor to do something along the lines of
"\n BAD_CODE thiswebsite.com" and it would still say its safe even though its
not.

A vulnerability existed in two methods when passed a certain argument. Passing
this argument lead to backtracking in a regular expression which resulted in
extremly slow evaluation times. This method could be called repeatedly and
overflow the system.

A function for checking whether a URL input by a user is secure to go to
didn't work correctly. By prepending certain uncommon characters to a URL,
the function could be made to accept URLs would otherwise be rejected
e.g. ones that would execute javascript.

The issue was in how Django was handling its sessions. It allowed
unauthenticated attackers to create numerous sessions records potentially 
causing a denial of service by filling up the session store or evicting 
other user's records.

Django would create a new empty record in the session storage every time 
'request.session' was accessed with a non-existing session key in the 
request cookies. To exploit the vulnerability, attackers can easily send 
in repeated requests with unknown session keys.

This vulnerability occurred because a script for compiling messages was written but the inputs were not being checked to make sure that they were not malicious in nature. The script's job was to make OS-level commands and if the inputs were not checked correctly, changes could be made to the system. If some of these commands are executed, hackers can take over the system by giving themselves access to files and system functions that they should not be able to reach normally.
The fix to this vulnerability was passing the input into a system tool that sanitizes and removes any possibly malicious strings or characters in the command like ";" and "$"

XML libraries for Python versions 3.4, 3.3, 3.2, 3.1, 2.7 and 2.6 allowed 
hostile attackers to make use of Denial-of-Service or DOS vulnerabilites via
an XML Entity Expansion or XEE attack. An XML Entity, also known as XML bombs
is a DOS attack, that expands expontially until it has exhausted a server's 
allocated resources. According to fortify.com, an attack can crash a servers
resources by nesting recurrent entity resolutions. This attack was used 
against various open source development stacks including Django.

This vulnerability has to do with the way Django handles cached data from sessions.
When using sessions, Django sets a specific header in responses that ensures that
cached data from one session is not served to requests from other sessions.
However, older versions of Interner Explorer could not handle this header with
certain content types, so the header was removed.

Removing this header created a potential vulnerability where the cache could
serve data from a different session. This could lead to improper disclosure of
data, or cache poisoning where an attacker floods the cache with malicious data
that is then unknowingly served to a user.

This vulnerability in Django caused underscore characters to be incorrectly
handled in certain headers in the system. The vulnerability allowed attackers
the ability to spoof headers in certain environments by using an underscore
instead of a dash. If a header was used in a way that was security-sensitive, even if
there was protection in place to strip characters, an attacker
could take advantage of the vulnerability and bypass this protection.

The fix now makes Django's built-in development server strip all the headers
that have underscores by default.

Cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerability in the admin section of Django that
allows remote attackers to inject arbitrary web script or HTML. The
vulnerability originated in fields intended to be read-only but allowed
data manipulation without sanitization or checks.

The vulnerability was in Django's built in validators, which are callables that 
take in an input value and raises a ValidationError if the input does not meet the
specified criteria. The validators described in the vulnerability report was the
following - EmailValidator, URLValidator, the validate_ip4_address 
(validator for ip4 addresses), and the validate_slug validator (which validates the 
part of a url that is used when accessing a resource). 

The specified validators above did not prohibit newline characters due to the
usage of $ instead of \Z in the regular expressions. Due to this, there was the
possibility of header injections which would allow HTTP response splitting attacks
via a newline character since the validators accepted newlines in the input.

There is a vulnerability that causes Open redirects in the django middleware.
This vulnerability occurs when certain settings are enabled and the URL pattern
accepts paths ending in slash. This allows attackers to create maliciously crafted
URLs that can lead to redirects to other sites.

A vulnerability in Django was found that could allow an unauthenticated, 
remote attacker to cause a denial of service condition on a targeted system.
The vulnerability can be found in the django.utils.html.urlize() function and is due to
insufficient validation of user provided input. To exploit this vulnerability an attacker could
submit a crafted input to an affected system and cause a denial of service attack on the targeted system.

If a two certain methods in the Django code base were passed a certain argument value, then they were
super slow to complete, due to a catastrophic backtracking vulnerability in a regular expression trying to truncate the string.
This vulnerability could've led to a denial-of-service attack if an attacker had
control over the input of the certain functions and created a string that would cause the backtracking.

By specifically crafting a url, an attacker could cause spoofed information 
appear on the Django default 404 webpage. The method that rendered the
template would reflect the given url in the 404 page. An attacker could make
a url that contains html tags that would render as part of the page. This 
leaves open the opportunity for XSS or CSRF.

The vulnerability exists in the way XML parsers and libraries used by Django
handle XML deserialization.
The implementation, which takes an XML and constructs into an object from the
structured data, does not handle parsing correctly. The DOCTYPE element
of XML can be injected with dangerous customized entities that are loaded
outside of the application.
Attackers can take advantage of this vulnerability by injecting network requests
via entity declaration in the DOCTYPE element of XML, forwarding and rebounding
with the server, and finally gaining read access to files. The server may also
take long time to process those requests, resulting in a DoS attack.

This CVE involves improper sanitization of user inputs(a cookie in this case). This means that arbitrary code including HTML can
be run by getting an authenticated user to click a link that includes the code. This CVE represents a vulnerability to
XSS(Cross Site Scripting) which means that a malicious hacker could execute code through a trusted and
unaware user. By sanitizing the inputs, Django would prevent this from happening as no inputs that involve code could
ever make it past validation without being modified to be safe. The portion of the project affected by this was a system
in Django that would detect and prevent CSRF attacks.

The issue involves Django's admin portal and inline related models. These are 
parent and child models displayed as nested forms in their respective 
admin page. The issue only occurs with users that have permission to edit the child 
model but not the parent. When the user clicks save on the page, Django first checks
which models the user has permission to edit and only run the save() method on those
models. In this situation the save() method being triggered should only be the
child's, but the vulnerability causes both parent and child methods to be called.
The user cannot actually edit the parent model but triggering the save() method can 
cause things like the pre and post-save handlers to be invoked.
There is no general issue for invoking the pre/post-save handlers, other than the 
clear permissions violation. Looking through the code, any issue would really depend 
on how they're implemented. If they're expecting changes then a runtime exception 
might occur. There could be an issue if the handlers are resource-intensive but 
only authorized users can access the admin portal, so there's a low chance of a DOS 
attack.

When Django's ModelAdmin objects were configured to enable "save_as", 
this allows a user with "change" but not "add" permission
to illegitimately create new ModelAdmin objects using the 
"Save as new" option when editing existing ModelAdmin objects.

This stemmed from the "Save as new" form submitting under change permissions,
even though it is really an add action.

Note that "save_as" was disabled by default, decreasing the number
of users potentially affected by the issue.

Django relies on user input in some cases, such as authentication users and internationalization, to redirect the user to another web page.
The security check for these redirects (namely django.utils.http.is_safe_url()) considered some numeric URLs (e.g. http:999999999) "safe" when they should
not have been considered safe. If a developer relies on is_safe_url() to provide safe redirect targets and puts such a URL into a link, they could suffer from an XSS attack.

Site running on Django could be crashed by a denial of service attack, by accessing a logout page without the proper credentials. This would result in denial of service by allowing a malicious actor to create an arbitrary number of empty sessions on the server, which could eventually cause a crash.
A malicious url was inserted into a view, which allowed for redirecting to any domain. The view is used to serve any directory that is provided, and was mainly for development, not for production.

This vulnerability deals with the security of user data in regards to Django
forms. Due to a regression in an earlier version, the confirm_login_allowed()
method would run regardless of whether or not the correct password was entered
which is not the desired functionality. While this would still throw an error,
the contents of the error could reveal to an attacker sensitive details about
the account. This data could include whether or not the account is marked as
active, in addition to more sensitive data.

When Django attempted to validate a url with a regular expression, certain
inputs would cause the regular expression engine to 'catastrophically
backtrack' leading to a drop in availability and a denial of service.
The url's that would cause this issue have 'trailing junk' past the top
level domain ('.com', '.org').
In this case 'catastrophically bactrack' may refer to the regex engine.
Or regular expression engine. Which takes is a regular expression pattern,
that can be used to search text for matches. Backtracking occurs when a
regex pattern causes the engine to search for as much text as possible,
and if the engine does not find a match at the biggest size possible, it
backs up and tries a slighty smaller match. The 'catastrophic' in this
case may cause very slow match times (not specified) that would contribute
to lack of availibility.

In Django, a vulnerability was discovered when using their provided middleware and backend
for remote users. In some circumstances, one user could receive another user's session
information. This would occur when the backend fails to authenticate a user with another
user logged in.

There was a vulnerability in the file upload system in the way it handled uploading files when the file name already existed in the system. The behavior was that an underscore and a number would be appended, and the number would increment until the new file had a unique name. There was a denial of service when someone uploaded a group of files with the same name, as it contiunally incremented the count.
It's possible to send malicious code to a server by putting in the proper sequence of characters to bypass input sanitization, letting people get unrestricted access to the server's database.

Django's contains a helper function, Reverse(), that can generate a URL from a 
reference to a view function or URL pattern name.  When presented with two forward 
slashes (//), this function could be used to generate scheme-relative URLs to other 
hosts.  This allows an attacker to commit phishing and other attacks.

The vulnerability is in the utility method strip_tags(), which takes an input string
and strips all the html tags from it. However, when an input string containing large
sequences of nested incomplete html entities is passed in, the method would become 
extremely slow.

Django includes both a caching framework and a system for preventing cross-site
request forgery (CSRF) attacks. The CSRF-protection system is based on a
random cookie sent to the client which must be sent by the client on future
requests and, in forms, a hidden value which must be submitted back with
the form.

The caching framework includes an option to cache responses to
anonymous (i.e., unauthenticated) clients.

When the first anonymous request to a given page is by a client which did not
have a CSRF cookie, the cache framework will also cache the CSRF cookie and
serve the same cookie to other anonymous clients who do not have a CSRF cookie.
This can allow an attacker to obtain a valid CSRF cookie value and perform
attacks which bypass the check for the cookie.

Django is a web framework that allows you to create Python classes/functions
to process certain urls. To convert between the string of the url the user
types in on their browser to the function/class that should handle the
request, the Django urlresolver's reverse function needs to lookup the
correct function/class. If A malicious hacker was able to insert malicious
code into the application, they could use this inherent trust of the system
to then look up the malicious code and run it using "dotted Python path",
or in other words, path traversal.

Django has the built in ability to generate a TEST database to be able to
create test tables and accounts to run unit tests againt so that it
doesn't mess up the actual live database you are using. While you were
able to specify a password, if you didn't, it would use a hardcoded one
instead. Therefore, if you ended up passing the `keepdb` flag when testing
anyone who looked on the repo and found that hardcoded password
could then gain access to your database server using the default
credentials. This was only applicable when using an Oracle database.

Older versions of Django don't validate the Host header against
settings.ALLOWED_HOSTS when settings.DEBUG=True.
This makes them vulnerable to a DNS rebinding attack.

A getter function belonging to a utility file in Django, which existed before  the patched version allowed remote attackers to obtain sensitive application secrets  via a settings key in place of a date/time format setting. This allowed a malicious user  to pass a secret key instead of a date format and obtain said application secret.

There is a potential cross-site scripting vulnerability in Django's
backend. Filenames for file input in forms aren't sanizited and special 
uri characters aren't escaped, potentially allowing code or html injection.

When logging into an administrator account, an attacker could perform XXS or
cross site scripting to inject an action into a form.  This would target a user
and execute the code that was injected into the form.  This would give the
attacker access to the target's information and potentially access tokens.
This could also allow the attacker to take actions on the site as the target.
In Django, the request path was not being escaped, which created an opportunity
for attackers to inject an XXS attack.

The administration application in Django stores unauthenticated HTTP POST
requests. After successful authentication, these requests are processed.
Remote attackers may use this in a cross-site request forgery (CSRF) attack
to delete or modify data.
This vulnerability is just for advisory, it does not have a patch.

The get_image_dimensions function in the image-handling functionality in Django before 1.3.2 and 1.4.x before 1.4.1 uses a constant chunk size to determine dimensions. Remote attackers could cause a denial of service (process or thread consumption) via a large TIFF image.

While logic was being implemented the developer missed an edge case. 
The error came from MySQL type casting where mixing types can causes 
unexpected results to be returned

Django is a high level web framework for python. It aims to make it easy
to create database driven websites. Django has many types of models for
web forms, one of which is a model that creates a web form that allows for
multiple options to be selected and submitted. When this model was using a
flag to add a hidden input of the initial data, an attacker could
cause multiple SQL queries by submitting duplicate values in the form,
causing a DoS on the Database.

The session flush method does not sychronize properly with the database, in which the session key is set to a empty
string instead of none. This means anyone with a empty string in their session key can login that person's account.

there was a XSS vulnerability present in django. This was a lower
risk vulnerability because it was only present on a page that is only
available given debug = true. Since most production sites will not have
debug = true this is lower risk.

Django is a high level web framework for python. It aims to make it easy
to create database driven websites. This vulnerability would not correctly
transfer a client from HTTP to HTTPS even when these proxying settings were
configured in Django. For example if the request went to the proxy
with HTTPS, the proxy might send it to Django with HTTP, but a secure header
along with the request. Django would typically interpret this secure header
in order to treat the incoming HTTP request as HTTP. With the vulnerability,
this secure header would not be read correctly, resulting in the request
being HTTP when it should be HTTPS. This vulnerability could result in
unencrypted packets being sniffed due to a man in the middle
attack or similar.

When passing certain inputs the django.utils.encoding.uri_to_iri conversion goes into excessive recursion when url encoding 
 invalid UTF-8 octet sequences.

Excessive memory usage can be caused by trying to format a Decimal to a string
that has a large number of digits or a large exponent.

FFmpeg.description:
A forgotten bounds check in a decoding helper function allowed remote attackers 
to execute a denial of service (DoS) via an out of bounds array access. There
was also the potential for unspecified further impact by specifically crafted
files.

This was purely a missed check, as the identical check exists elsewhere in multiple
other locations in the function.

A user could pass a corrupted RealMedia file (RealMedia being an audio/video
file format) to FFmpeg and corrupt the heap as a result.

This in theory could allow a malicious actor to corrupt the heap with actual code.
This code could then be executed from within the program, giving the malicious actor any
number of advantages depending on what the code did.

An attacker may use a particularly crafted video file in the Matroska format,
which is just a file format that can hold video, audio, picture or subtitle
tracks. This malicious file may hog CPU processing power when scanning text in the file
enclosed in braces, thus causing Denial of Service. This is a direct result of
using scanf with Mastroka files.

A read function in ffmpeg does not restrict reload attempts for an insufficient list, so a denial of service via infite loop can occur. An attacker can abuse the insufficient list by constantly reloading and making the program attempt to read it. This can cause a crash as eventually a loop will overflow. A reload is just a refresh attempt at reading the list, and an insufficent list is just a list that doesn't meet the requirements to be read.

When encoding an 8-bit video with the MPEG4 codec, there is a check to ensure
the supported MPEG4 profile for 8-bit video, Simple Studio Profile, is being used. 
Profiles are basically different specifications aimed at optimizing encoding/decoding
for a particular video type, which are then implemented into actual software. 
The active profile is tracked by both the MPEG4 encoder and the decoder from 
the original video, and both values are checked throughout the system to 
ensure only supported profiles are being used. However, the decoding source 
can change throughout the encoding process. The AVI video format consists
of "chunks" of video strung together. These chunks can actually
be using completely different compression codecs, including MPEG4. 
So using an AVI file that has an MPEG4 chunk that could be 
decoded with a different profile could cause the profile check to fail, 
causing an error to be thrown and stopping the conversion process.
While the decoder attempts to correctly switch the profile back and forth
when encoding and decoding, it is not perfect, so hitting the assertion 
is still very likely.

The bug involved a race condition which could corrupt data. Various threads 
involved in encoding/decoding the audio and video could accidentally work on
the same frame at the same time. Because this was shared data, depending on
the order the threads accessed it in, it could lead to unexpected behavior 
like corrupt files or segfaults whenever someone tried to decode a video in
multithreaded mode.

A memory corruption vulnerabilty for audio conversion allowing 
an attacker to inject remote attacks using vectors related to channel layout 
(i.e. av_get_channel_layout_nb_channels). By exploiting this vulnerabilty, 
the attacker can alter the intended control flow, read sensitive information,
and even cause the system to crash.

The avcodec_decode_audio4 method performs read and write operations to the 
memory location that is outside the bounds of the memory buffer.

When converting from a modified AVI (Audio Video Interleave) file to an MPEG4 
file, a logic check would compare two fields of a studio profile that could 
potentially not be the same or even not instantiated. This could led to a 
NULL pointer dereference that could crash the system, leading to a denial 
of service.

Audio Video Interleave, known by its initials AVI and the .avi filename 
extension, is a multimedia container format introduced by Microsoft in 
November 1992 as part of its Video for Windows software. AVI files can 
contain both audio and video data in a file container that allows 
synchronous audio-with-video playback.

An MPEG4 file is a video file saved in the MPEG-4 container format. It 
includes both audio and video data and supports multiple A/V codecs. MPEG4 
files are commonly used for distributing video content over the web and for 
streaming videos on the Internet. MPEG4 files typically have an . MP4 file 
extension.

There was a Heap-based buffer overflow vulnerability in ffmpeg's implementation of a 
multimedia streaming server for live broadcasts that allows attackers to execute 
arbitrary code by leveraging failure to check chunk size. 

Initial inception of the vulnerability was in 1988 and was nicknamed the 
Morris Internet worm. In ffserver.c, the buffer overflow was caused by not 
checking for a negative chunk_size, which immediately resulted in rip control 
and then code execution

In FFmpeg, a remote attacker could execute arbitrary code on the system. 
This can cause an error in the smacker_decode_header_tree() function. 
Smacker is video file format that is used for full-motion video; it is often used in video games.
The format was reversed engineered and implemented in libavcodec, a subsystem in FFmpeg. 
By persuading a victim to open a corrupt file, a remote attacker could exploit this vulnerability to execute arbitrary code on the system.

When parsing audio visual data for Huffyuv codec files, a lossless Win32 video codec,
various error conditions like invalid input formats, empty lengths, etc. can occur. 
If one of these are hit, an error code is returned, indicating something went wrong.

In this case the error return codes from functions in the Huffyuv decoder are never checked.
Additionally, some basic checks, such as ensuring the file isn't empty, are never made.
Together these allow an attacker to sneak an empty or invalid file in, which will result 
in an out of bounds write. This write can lead to disruptions, Denial of Service, and other
unintended behaviors.

A vulnerability that allows the system to read out of the array when reading the 
contents of an ASF file from user input. An ASF file is a video or audio file 
stored in advanced systems format. In this case, the system was reading the exact 
number of bytes expected in the ASF file. This would allow an attacker to submit 
a corrupt ASF file with a different number of bytes in it, causing the system to 
read a different memory location, and possibly leaking data. This vulnerability 
was mitigated by checking how many bytes are left before reading, and returning 
an "AVERROR_INVALIDDATA" error if the ASF file does not have the expected number 
of bytes.

In order to decode a RL2 file, a video codec for the 1993 adult video game 
"Vouyer", the system must first pass it through a demuxer, a process that 
separates the audio and video data into seperate streams of information that 
can be easily used by the rest of the system. The RL2 file has a header that 
specifies the amount of frames the video will have. It then uses this value
to go through each frame and get three values, the size of both the video and 
audio data, how far away the frame is from the start of the file, and the size 
of just the audio data. However, there is no check for an end of file character 
in these loops, which could lead to a potential Denial of Service attack. An 
attacker could modify the number of frames in the header to a very large 
number, which could cause the program to loop through this process much more 
than intended. Since the program needs to save the chunk and audio frame data,
a bunch of garbage data could fill up the systems memory, and put a large strain
on the systems CPU. This could make either the machine or software unusable.

When processing video media, non-Haar wavelets are used to transform 
the pixels in the frame. With how non-Haar wavelets behave, they need 
to look outside of the frame. If not properly padded on all sides of 
the frame, this could cause a boundary condition error (similar to a 
out of bounds exception with an array) and a denial of service. The 
current functionality only pads the bottom and left part of the video 
frame. The solution corrects this by padding on all four sides of the 
frame. This is done with the slice width and height.

Note: When looking across the web, there was very little about non-Haar wavelets. 
Whatever I could find were scholary articles that I did not have access and/or 
could not get access to. What I could find was on Haar wavelets and they are 
blocky waves/oscillations. Think sin/cos functions but rather than a wavy pattern
it is square-shaped.

This vulnerability is an out of array write. There is a type of data in signal
processing, called PARCOR coefficients, and the code contains an array of these.
In the process of decoding an audio file, those coefficients are an efficient
way of defining the shape of the audio wave. The system did not care whether 
those coeffients were accurate, and assumed they corresponded exactly to the 
rest of the audio data provided. This could lead to a write out of bounds during
the process of decoding, leading to memory corruption.

When parsing audio-visual data for Ut Video Codec files, a fast and lossless video codec, 
no check is done for the length and integrity of the inputted file. Should this file 
change in size during the decoding process or be carefully crafted such that the format 
is against specifications, an out of array read occurs, leading to a potential 
Denial of Service. 
Attackers could craft files empty or variable length files leading to crashes, 
threatening the integrity and availability of any system running FFmpeg.

A lack of validation for the number of components in a Lossless JPEG, that
allows for original data to be perfectly reconstructed from the compressed
data, at the start of the frames segement, where a one byte field is always
set to 10101011. This leads to allowing remote attackers to make a machine or
network resource unavailable to its intended users by temporarily or
indefinitely distrupting services of a host connected to the Internet. Which
can be done by flooding the targeted machine or resource with requests to try
an overload systems and prevent requests from being fufilled. The lack of
validation also can lead to allowing attackers to possibly have unspecified
other impact through each video frame or interlaced field of digital video
sequences being compressed separately as a JPEG image.

When decoding a frame of an encoded video, FFmpeg first copies the data for
that frame into an array. If the data is copied successfully, a boolean is
set to "true" to indicate this. After decoding the frame, there is logic to
