skip some number of audio samples at the beginning of the frame
(if a number of samples was specified).

The skipping logic was being executed without checking if the frame data was
copied successfully. In the case where copying failed, the code would try
to access nonexistent elements in the frame data array, thus causing an
application crash (i.e. a denial of service). Attackers could craft audio
data to cause this scenario.

The fix was simple: before performing the skip operation, verify that the
copying was successful via the aforementioned boolean.

In the code that handles the crafting of Apple Lossless Audio Codec, there was a
vulnerability that allowed remote attackers to have an unknown level of impact on
the system by submitting too large a value to a variable called nb_samples. This
would cause possible denial of service, as too large a number would cause
a for loop to iterate that many times.

This vulnerability deals with a potentially unhandled index out of bounds
write in a VQA (Vector Quantized Animation) decoding function. VQA is a file
format used by multiple different video games produced by Westwood Studios. Due
to the lack checking the current chunk size, attackers could potentially cause
the software to write outside of the bounds of the allocated array, likely 
causing misbehavior in other parts of the software, or potentially directly
causing the system to crash if trying to write outside the bounds of the
allocated memory for the application.

A library function #get_qcx(..., int n, ...), in libavcodec, is responsible
for decoding the quantization parameters for a jpeg2000 / "J2K" datastream.
In simple terms, these byte-for-byte parameters specify how to compress the
image. Note the fix was likely just responding to a warning, as no code flows
(in the code at the time) would have permitted this overflow to occur.

The parameter of interest in this vulnerability is "n". This variable is the
length of the quantiziation parameter that was last read in merely adding a
check if n was greater than 96 (larger than the bounds of the array it reads
values into), then this overflow would occur. However, due to the fact that
"n" is constrained by "bytestream2_get_be16u"'s return value, it can only
range from 1 to 16, depending on the bitlength of the input. Overall, it would
seem this was not truly a vulnerability to begin with, but rather something
that could have become a vulnerability in the future.

In FFmpeg, colors in a video frame are encoded using "planes", which are sets of bits representing the colors of each pixel in the image. For a single frame, FFmpeg stores several planes as well as the "stride" of each plane, which is a number related to the width and height of the frame. An attacker may craft a video file wherein one of the planes may have a plane with no associated stride value. The code would then try to access the stride for that plane (an alement in an array), which does not exist (i.e. out-of-bounds). This may cause an application crash or other negative impact.

A decode frame function in the cdgraphics file does not account for non-header
data when reading from the video buffer to a new one. This meant that
attackers could insert more data than expected, causing the subsequent read
to overflow from the array it was being read into. This would cause an out of
bounds array access error, the application crashing, and a denial of service
atack.

A user could pass a carefully crafted RealVideo file (RealVideo being a video
file format) to FFmpeg and, because some fields of a certain struct were not
initialized, the user could cause a crash, leading to a denial of service 
attack due to invalid pointer access.

It has been theorized (but never tested in practice) that depending on how
the input file was crafted, there could be other consequences of exploiting
the vulnerability.

A decoder function in file is creating a stack to decode to. When creating
the stack, it is specified to be a minimum size of 1. This is too small, and
the stack should be at least a size of 2 When the application then tries to
write to it, a stack overflow can occur on a stack of size one getting passed
at two points of data. This causes errors and the application to
crash. It was automatically assigned a severity of "high" by the fuzzing
software that found it. This is most likely because it causes an application crash.

A missing End of File (EOF) check in the code responsible for splitting
Material eXchange Format (mxf) files into their basic components (audio,
video, etc) could cause a Denial of Service attack via a specifically crafted
mxf file. Specifically, the mxf file would need to specify an arbitrarily
large amount of data in its header, without sufficient data to back it up. The
file could also cause this unterminated loop to run multiple times, which could
be used to potentially mask the malicious nature of the file by utilizing a
smaller number of index entries in the header. The DoS is done by consuming
large quantities of CPU resources.

Interestingly, this vulnerability appears to be specifically tied to this missing
EOF check, and does not appear to create vulnerabilities within the other
methods that it calls, depsite the potential for bad data to be passed to them.

This vulnerability had the potential for a Denial of Service to occur. This is
because of a for loop that didn't check for an end of file character at any 
point. Essentially cine file being read in could claim to be much larger than
it was, and the for loop that was running through it would trust that input, 
rather than checking for an end of the file itself. This would lead the system to 
hang with high cpu and ram consumption as it continued to read in data beyond
what it should.

This is a case of not taking in user input correctly, so after it was finished
using the data, it wasn't cleared correctly. This meant that data was still 
being referenced after it wasn't needed, which had the potential to cause a 
denial of service through an invalid pointer access error. Before the fix, it
was just calling memset on the four pointers being referenced, when in reality
it should have been setting all attributes of the MpegEncContext variable to 
NULL as well.

This leads to allowing remote attackers to make a machine or network resource
unavailable to its intended users by temporarily or indefinitely distrupting
services of a host connected to the Internet. Which can be done by flooding
the targeted machine or resource with requests to overload the system and
prevent requests from being fufilled. Due to the nature of this issue,
code-execution may be possible that could possibly have unspecified other impact
through a crafted high-definition video post-production encoder and decoder
device file (DNxHD file).

A buffer overflow vulnerability that allows attackers to utilize a long 
filename in order to trigger an out-of-array access issue. The source of 
this issue is the use of the strcpy function on a filename string without 
input validation in libavfilter/vf_signature.c. 
A buffer overflow in this scenerio could cause the service to crash 
(resulting in a denial of service). This vulnerability could also cause 
the strcpy function to overwrite another memory location, causing a loss 
of data.

Given a specificly crafted video file, a remote attacker can trigger an array
out-of-bounds error causing total shutdown of the service. Additionally during
the failure condition, the error log would produce a list of affected files. This
results in a integrity violation due to the disclosure of system files.

This vulnerability allows for attackers to suject the system to a denial of
service via an attempted array read out of bounds. This occurs in the 
jpeg2000_decode_tile() function, which handles the decoding of a jpeg2000 image
file. Because the code does not take into account the component number in
calculations done, there is a potential out of bounds read, which would be likely
to result in a crashed system.

This vulenrability was in h264_ps.c that does not validate the relationship 
between the depths of luma and chroma. H.264 is the codec that is widely used
with penetration in streaming video markets, broadcast, etc. Codec is a device
or program that compresses data to enable faster transmission and decompresses
received data. In video, luma represents the brightness of the pixel and 
chroma represents the color information. They are typically paired up. The 
existing check in libavcodec in FFmpeg before 1.1.3 is not validating if the
depths of luma and chroma do not match. 

The way this could be exploited is that an attacker can cause a denial of
service due to out-of-bounds array access. At best, the application will
crash. At worst, there will be unspecified impacts through crafted H.264 data.

When gifdec.c is reading a GIF, the height of an image may not be properly computed. This allows a crafted GIF to 
allow an attacker to write code outside of the allocated space. This results in an out-of-bounds access, allowing 
attackers to make the system crash, and possibly make execute arbitrary code.

FFmpeg did not restrict file extensions when reading Apple HTTP Live Streaming 
(HLS) playlist data nor when reading subtitle demuxer names (modules designed to 
extract subtitle data), which allowed attackers to access arbitrary files 
via a malicious HLS playlist.

A vulnerability in mpeg video decoding, where the decoder will only keep track
of image size changes through the set "dimensions" of each frame's image (and
not accounting for the "bits per pixel" of the frame). This allows remote
attackers to make use of data with non-standard bytes-per-pixel in order to
over or underflow the backing memory buffer.

The bits-per-pixel has to do with the eventual bit-width of what you read for
a pixel's value. In RGB you could have 3 ints, which could individually be
32 bits, or 16 bits, etc. By setting an amount per-pixel (as opposed to or in
addition to the dimensions), ffmpeg won't know how many bits to read at each
pixel from the input. Naturally if you expect N pixels but only get N/2, you
will end up reading another N/2 of overflow memory.

A specially crafted input stream could cause a segfault and crash related 
to the AMF(Action Message Format) files used to communicate with real time
sources of Audio and Video data such as commercial video streaming software 
or Adobe Flash. The segfault was caused by a function taking two arguments, 
a begin pointer and an end pointer with no input validation being performed.
An attacker could use this to crash FFmpeg while it's trying to recieve an 
inputstream.

A certain object called a frame has different types. A frame can have multiple different 
processes that do separate things. One of these types was being checked for out of array access, 
but all others were not. This vulnerability was because those other frame types were able 
to trigger out of array access if their id was too large. 
This only happened while converting an AVI file to MPEG4. This
vulnerability would crash the program, causing a denial of service.

The vulnerability exists in a parser for ID3; ID3 is a metadata container commonly used in MP3 files that stores information like title, play counter, and equalization. 
By adding a very long metadata container to a video, an attacker could write to memory outside of the allocated buffer. 
This allows an attacker to possible make the program crash by overriding code necessary for the program to run, or execute arbitrary code.
By executing arbitrary code, attackers can potentially delete, view, or alter the information in the system.

The issue describes a potential denial of service attack when attempting to decode
a particular .ogg file in the Vorbis OGG decoder. To give some background, 
OGG is a file format that allows multiple streams of data to be embedded into
a single file format. Vorbis OGG refers to the audio coding format that is
used to embed audio, and Vorbis OGG is commonly associated with the .ogg
file extension. The Vorbis decoder refers to converting the digital audio
signals (digitally transferable) back into analog audio signals
(humanly audible).

Upon a specific section of the decoding process (decoding the ‘floor’), 
it was possible for the decode function to yield a negative value. 
Essentially, the issue was that the decode function previously returned an unsigned int, 
leading to an Integer Overflow type vulnerability, where a ‘negative’ unsigned int 
would wrap around to a very large number. This integer overflow vulnerability was 
reported to cause a crash. An attacker could potentially create a malicious .ogg file, which
would crash the overall system upon decoding. The mitigation for this was to change the return type 
to an integer and to explicitly check the returned integer for a negative value.

This issue describes a potential denial of service attack or possibly even
arbitrary code execution within the functionality of decoding via DPCM.
To give some background, DPCM (Differential Pulse Code Modulation) is a 
method used to encode and decode audio information, and is commonly used 
with AVI files. 

Specifically, the vulnerability is likely due to extraneous 
memory buffers being unintentionally read. As a result, an attacker could 
theoretically craft a special stream of data to be decoded by the DPCM decoder, 
and have that data contain a pointer that executes undesired code. 
The same concept could also be used to create a denial of service attack. 
This vulnerability is similar to that of a buffer overflow. The fix for this 
vulnerability was to decrease the memory buffer, so that no unintended data 
is read or written by the decoder.

VP5/VP6 are lossy compression formats that ffmpeg can convert. By making malignant VP5/VP6 streams an attacker can cause an out-of-bounds read which would cause the program to crash. Sensitive information exposure is also  possibility for out-of-bounds reads, but doesn't seem to be the issue with this CVE since its defined as 'denial of service'.

Information could be read past the end of an output buffer, resulting in an
application crash or arbitrary code execution. The vulnerability is exploited 
with a specially crafted media file, and it would allow the attacker to force 
the buffer to continue reading farther into the heap than should be permitted.

A file in ffmpeg allowed a denial of service and possibly execution of arbitrary code because of an invalid free. Invalid Frees happen when a pointer could be freed twice. This can cause a memory leak which can crash a program and make a remote attacker able to possible execute arbitrary code.

The file where the vulnerability existed is of an Indeo Video Interactive decoder. 
Indeo Video is a family of audio a video formats. One function of the video 
interactive decoder was decoding a group of pictures (GoP) header. GoP is a collection 
of pictures within a video stream. The vulnerability was that there was no check 
regarding the validity of the GoP header being decoded. When looking through the commits 
and repository, there was no information regarding the failure that was observed. By 
obveserving the vulnerability, it is assumed that an attacker could potentially enter a
malicious input causing a buffer overflow.

The system is vulnerable to a denial of service, caused by an error in the prepare_sdp_description method. An attacker can exploit this CVE by using vectors,
in rtp format, to cause the system to crash. RTP format is a network protocol for delivering audio and video over IP networks. A lack of testing, no maintenance, and design cause 
this bug because the developers did not consider all different use cases.

This vulnerability allows for remote attackers to take advantange of a lack
of input validation for the decompression of MJPEG (Motion JPEG, created when each image in
a video is turned into a JPEG) files. Specifically, the start and end coefficient for the scan
that occurs when decompressing a MJPEG could have been altered in ways(such as the start being
after the end, or having values too large) that could write into other buffers.

The vulnerability was in libavcodec/h264.c that does not properly check the
input whenever there is a change in the pixel format. The existing check for
the pixel input before FFmpeg 1.1.2 is not sufficient to detect a pixel format
change. This resulted in improper input validation that the data is not 
processed correctly. It will crash due to out-of-bounds array access.

The way this could be exploited is that an attacker can have an 
impact through H.264 video data which will not be specified for developers 
to figure out what impact it will cause.
The input and output weren't verified properly so an attacker could supplant their own. This means that they could enter data from an unkown source and send data to an unknown repository.

The vulnerability is an issue with type casting in C. When the original code was run,
a value used in a "for" loop conditional would be cast to an unsigned datatype automatically.
This could cause the loop to run for longer than intended and access data that it's not
supposed to access. Explicitly casting the unsigned datatype to a signed integer makes the result
of the whole calculation a signed integer, which prevents an out-of-bounds read.

Due to a lack of checking for a zero value of a slice of an array, a remote attacker could
cause an out-of-bounds array access error, due to the array slice being empty, which could
potentially deny service, or worse.

When decoding JPEG 2000 (successor format to JPEG) files, it did not check 
if there was duplicate size markers (markers are bytes stored in JPEG files 
designed to hold extra data), allowing a buffer overflow to occur.

Heap-based interger overflow vulnerabilty that allowed remote attackers to specify
image file dimensions too large for a buffer in an interactive session of Indeo, 
a compression / decompression technology. This buffer would then overflow and 
compromise other data leading to integrity and / or the availability of the system 
being compromised depending on where in memory the buffers overflowed to.

A function that decodes JPEG2000 compression does not check the level of 
compression on the JPEG2000 file being decompressed. This can lead to a situation
where a specially crafted JPEG2000 file can be manipulated to cause an index out
of bounds error. This index out of bounds can be used by an attacker who has
crafted a JPEG2000 file to crash a remote system through FFmpeg.

An out-of-bounds array access could be triggered by a user crafting a custom .avi file that would cause an error
in performing row calculations.

Function was vulnerable to an infinite loop due to the improper management
of system resources. An infinite loop can cause the CPU to run near 100% 
utilization and prevent other programs from running, leading to a 
potential denial of service. In this particular case, it was due to the 
decoding of a modified AVI (Audio Video Interleave) file that contained 
a type structure that was used in the reading of Nikon tags.

When parsing the header of a "Real" compatible media file, the parser failed
to check for an End-Of-File (EOF) character. This leads to a potential Denial
of Service via an infinite loop on a specially-crafted IVR media file.
The attacker would provide a high "length" value but not provide enough data
for it, then the end of file would come and the parser would keep going.

The library does not properly validates widths and heights of a passed-in
MPEG stream. An attacker can utilize this to craft a video which has actual
width/heights (in-content) less than specified (causing an integer underflow),
or by providing a video with content bigger than specified (causing an
out-of-array read, a classic variation of a buffer overflow).

Given a specifically created video file, when FFmpeg uses a video decoder, a null-pointer-exception can be thrown.
This causes an uncaught failure terminating the process.

.cdxl files are a type of video format that was used to display video on the
Commodore Amiga. This vulnerability is caused by the .cdxl decoding not
checking if the file being decoded was in the CHUNKY format. Not checking
this allowed a specially crafted .cdxl file to cause a target buffer overflow
attack.

When analyzing a waveform audio file, if you get a malformed audio file that doesn't
contain any samples, it could cause a divide by 0 error.

CVE-2018-6621 forces a video bytestream to extend past the normally allowed 
amount, resulting in an out-of-bounds read, a crash, and thus a denial of 
service. This vulnerability can be exploited with a maliciously crafted AVI 
file.

The file hevcdec.c included an insufficient check for duplicate data
in a file of a specific type, HEVC, a video type in the same family as
MPEG-4 or MP4. This mishandling becomes relevant when the Network
Abstraction Layer (NAL) type of a picture is Random Access Skipped
Leading (RASL), and causes a null pointer exception. More information
on HEVC picture types can be found here:
https://www.hevcbook.de/hevc-picture-types/

A vulnerablility allowed a maliciously crafted mpeg-4, which is a popular 
audio and video fileformat, to cause a crash in the mpeg-4 studio profile 
decoder by accesing an array index out of bounds. This caused by video files intentionally having bad data. An attacker could use this vulnerability to 
crash FFmpeg while it's reading a media file.

systemd.description:
Systemd used to mishandle how numerical usernames get handled.
Usernames that contain decimal digits or even "0x" followed by hexadecimal
digits get handled incorectly. The issue exists due to an incomplete fix from
CVE-2019-1000082 which only fix handling decimal values and not octal (having a
leading 0 such as 0500 read as 320 in decimal) or hexadecimal such as 0x2b3bfa0.
The use of 0x0 user accounts were suppose to be an intended feature.
Successful exploitation of this vulnerability could lead to disclosure of sensitive
information, addition or modification of data, or Denial of Service (DoS).

If a process tries to mount and access a drive/network share while the autof process is trying to auto-mount the drive/network share, a race condition can happen where auto-mounts can fail causing the original mount to fail. This can be used by a remote user to cause a denial of service.

The native journal protocol in systemd is responsible for parsing predefined log data into the program for testing purposes. Its original implementation introduced a vulnerability when combined with the previously existing logging functionality. Local users could make a maliciously-crafted file to force the logging module to block, causing later logging messages from systemd to not be recorded.

Systemd mishandled the check to the current keyboard mode which resulted in 
the mode of the virtual terminal being changed when a user logged out. 

This would allow a user with any level of privilege to briefly 
view passwords in cleartext displayed on the terminal console under 
specific circumstances such as watching a shutdown or switching back and
forth between the first console and a terminal window (easily achievable
with the keyboard shortcuts Ctrl-Alt-F1 and Ctrl-Alt-F2).

The fix for this vulnerability involved verifying the current keyboard
mode before changing it.

A function within systemd existed for selecting keyboard locales. When accessed by the administrative authentication function to change a particular privilege, it could be intercepted to allow all local users in the group the ability to elevate their privilege through the usage of vectors.

A race condition in a method for changing file/directory ownership in systemd 
allows an attacker to cause systemd to set arbitrary permissions on arbitrary 
files

In systemd's logging system, called journald, log messages must be terminated
with a colon. However, passing in just a colon caused the logger to crash.
Upon crashing, the adjacent memory is dumped to the console, which attackers
could use to create additional exploits (such as reading sensitive,
out-of-bounds information).

When a service is created in systemd, a new user is created with a unique user ID.
A user is only able to access resources assigned to its UUID. DynamicUsers are a more
recent addition to systemd that attempt to improve the user process. When a service using
a DynamicUser is terminated, it's UUID will also be freed, allowing a new process to claim
that identifier.

An issue with DynamicUser was discovered that would allow it to interact with the service 
that assigns UUIDs and gain additional IDs. Any resources created or used with these additional
identifiers would not be removed when the service would terminate and release the original UID 
assigned to its DynamicUser. If a new service is created and assigned the same UID that the 
malicous service was given, any leftover binaries may have access to the resources of the 
newly created service.

CVE-2018-15686 was a vulnerability in which arbitrary state could be injected
during the deserialiization of the state of a service. Service states longer
than the maximum line length were incorrectly parsed and overflow was read
during the next call to the relevant methods. This allowed for injection of
custom service and potentially escalation of privileges.

In a function that handles the parsing of specific DNS packets there was a non-terminating while loop caused by a continue statement that would cause any possible changes to the loop condition from happening. This infinite loop caused a potential for DoS attacks against services that made use of systemd-resolve to resolve DNS queries over DNSSEC. If a DNSSEC server were to be compromised and add one of these NSEC packets to its responses, it could potentially crash any services that attempt to resolve the response.
The only packets that would cause this infinite loop are so called NSEC packets, which are part of DNSSEC. DNSSEC stands for Domain Name Service Security Extensions. NSEC, which stands for Next Secure Record, packets allow a DNSSEC server to provide authenticated denial of the existence of a given record on the server.
The fix was to modify the loop from a while loop to a for loop. This removed the potential for an infinite loop.
Stack-based buffer overflow issue in the function responsible for getting host names for dynamic users, aka "temporary" users.

This vulnerability was in systemd versions 223-233 within the dns_packet_new() 
function.

Some sizes passed to the dns_packet_new() function would cause the function to
allocate too small of a buffer, leaving the system vulnerable to a buffer 
overflow. More specifically, sizes close to the page size would cause the 
function to allocate less memory than requested.

With this vulnerability, a malicious TCP transmission could be crafted by a 
remote user to trick the function into allocating a buffer that's too small and 
thus allow for arbitrary code execution beyond the end of the buffer.

A systemd services that used the DynamicUser property(assigns a unique UID to the service at run time) was able to
create SUID/SGID(saved user id/ saved group id) binaries that could later run as a
transient service. The DynamicUser property allows systemd to dynamicly assign a unique UID(user id) to the service.
The issue was that once the service had a UID any files that it created would have a SUID/SGID that maped to the UID
of the service that created it. Because of the SUID/SGID these transiant services were efectivly
allowed to run with the same privileges as the systemd service. An exploit could be used to write binaries that could
later be executed with elevated privlages and access resources owned by other services even after the systemd service
had been terminated.

A vulnerability in the Debian OS allowed a user to abuse a command within 
systemctl to create an arbitrary entry into the Linux systems service manager. By overloading the service list, 
the manager would fail during the login/boot phase of Debian resulting in a denial of service.

A buffer overflow in the DHCP6 client of systemd-networkd, a wireless and wired
connection manager utility for Linux, allowed malicious DHCP servers to overwrite
memory within systemd-networkd. This meant if you connected to a malicious network,
they could potentially execute code on your system without your knowledge or any
interaction.

Early versions of systemd contained an exploit in systemd-journald - a service
which collects and stores logging data, making use of the function syslog().
Certain programs that made syslog() function calls could crash systemd if an
extremely long number of command line arguments were given. This crash was
caused by poor memory allocation.

System crashes when an attacker sends large amount of entries into journald. System does not allocate memory properly and does not limit the total memory allocation so with a large number of entries, the system will allocate memory that clashes with a different memory region leading to systemd-journald crashing.

When a user accesses a site, a process occures where the site is interpreted as an IP address. A remote person may be able to intercept the IP address, when the user submits the site request, and then give the user's system the address to a malicious site or be able to find out what other sites the user has visited.

This was a stack buffer exploit. An unpriviledged user is able to send a message that resulted in a stack pointer to jump to a region of memory that triggered a denial of service causing the systemd PiD1 to crash

Inside of shared/bus-util.c, there is a call to sd_bus_set_trusted inside of
bus_open_system_watch_bind_with_description which changed the permissions on messages
sent to always have max permissions locally. Resulting in the ability for unpriviledged 
users to be able to execute methods that would be restricted to them, specifically about DNS configuration.

When file permissions are being updated in systemd, local users are able to use a symlink attack (redirecting a link's endpoint) to change the permissions and SELinux security contexts (rules that define who is given access to specific resources) for arbitrary files.

In not thoroughly checking the permissions information, a race condition could
be created in some circumstances. Specifically this happens via DBus and using
the execve() API call. The subsystem meant to handle this is polkit, which
specifies what daemon processes can do.

DBus allows for processes to run as a daemon and provide easy communication
with other processes and hardware. The polkit feature defines what behavior
is allowed. When setuid is activated, a race condition can occur leading to
the daemon's availability being violated.

The fix for the vulnerability was changing how the permissions were checked.

Inside the file resolved-dns-packet.c the function dns_packet_is_reply_for() does not check if the DNS (Domain Name System) response has an empty question section. If a empty question selection is passed it will trigger a null-pointer dereference and crash systemd.A malicious user could craft their DNS response to contain an empty question section in order to cause a denial of service.

An exploitable denial-of-service vulnerability exists in Systemd 245. A specially crafted IP renewal packet can cause a server running the client to be vulnerable to a IP address allocation/lease spoofing attack. An attacker can forge a pair of renweal and allocation/lease packets to reconfigure the server.

A heap use-after-free vulnerability was found in systemd,
where asynchronous Polkit, a component for controlling system-wide privileges in Unix-like functioning systems,
queries are performed while handling dbus messages. Dbus messages is a message-oriented middleware mechanism
that lets intercommunication between multiple processes running concurrently on the same machine.
A local unprivileged attacker can abuse this flaw to accident systemd services or
potentially effect code and raise their privileges by forwarding particularly crafted dbus messages.

Linux Kernel.description:
This vulnerability involves a data structure in the SCSI system where a message
received from a user through a network connection is read into a buffer without 
checking the size of it, which can lead to a buffer overflow, possibly causing
a DoS, information disclosure, or elevation of privilege.

This vulnerability was very basic, but had some dangerous implications: An 
unchecked, external string was being entered into method that calls 
"strlen()". In C, Strings must be null terminated (a null character must 
be at the end of every string, to signify its end). When strlen is called on
a string that is not null terminated, it will continue to look through memory 
until it hits a bit defined as null, which can result in undefined behavior. 
The affected subsystem uses an NFS (Network File Sharing) protocol to define 
error traces, which uses file names found in its file system daemon (NFSD).  
Since the input was from an external source (the names of files in the file 
system), and that input was not verified, it was possible that it could not 
be properly null terminated, and thus could result in the system behaving 
in an unintended fashion, and could even lead to a denial of service situation.
A NULL pointer deference flaw was found, where the way the user closes the wireless private network could allow them to crash the system

There was a vulnerability in the Linux kernel where the bpf module did not
validate numbers when translating from a 64 bit integer to an unsigned 32 bit
integer, resulting in local users being able to escalate privileges through
eBPF programs.

This vulnerbility is within the file that checks the validity of BPF instructions. 
BPF's are sandbox programs that allow for users to add extended functionality to Linux Kernel
without changing the Linux source code. 

Within this file the check_alu_op() method is responsible for checking the validity of 32-bit and 64-bit
arithmetic operations. In doing this the method failed to update the bounds. This allowed users to gain access to sensitive
information through pointer leaking.

A bug was found in the Linux kernel running on Power9 processors with how
registers are saved/restored when entering/leaving an idle state. This
occurs when the user has Kernel Userspace Address Protection enabled. The
function responsible for saving does not properly address several registers,
which may let a guest user render the system unusable (Denial of Service).

This is vulnerability can be exploited if an attacker has special privileges (root privileges) they can 
cause a Denial of Service and sensitive data leak if the list was not cleared by a function call.

The Linux kernel provides a tool called "perf", also known as "perf_events". 
Perf is an observability tool that allows you to better understand
your program's performance at the hardware level. Perf interacts with Linux's
performance subsystem by measuring hardware events such as the number of
instructions executed. Along the same lines, perf measures and logs the number
of functions in the stack. The vulnerability here is that perf does not
limit the number of functions that can be measured in the stack, meaning that
a user could create a stack layout with a very large number of functions and
cause perf to infinitely count the number of functions.
This infinite count results in an infinite loop, causing denial of service.
This vulnerability relates to poor resource management.
This vulnerability only applied to 64-bit big-endian PowerPC processors.
PowerPC is a family of processors, and the 64-bit big-endian PowerPC processor
is one specific processor in that family.

Users that are physically using a machine with Linux Kernel installed could cause denial of 
service if they remove a specific type of usb device (MAX-3421 USB device) in certain 
situations. The system would end up using the allocated memory that was already freed.

On the Linux kernel, a vulnerability was found where a local user could cause a denial
of service and panic the system when issuing the perf record command. This was the 
case on systems without any specific PMU driver support registered, and the highest 
threat from this vulnerability is to system availability. A PMU is a Performance Monitoring
Unit, which Linux Kernel provides for counting events such as cycles, instructions, and 
cache metrics.

The flaw originates from a race condition with linux kernel SCTP (Stream Control Transmission Protocol) sockets that
can lead to linux kernel privilege escalation from a network service or other
unprivileged process. If a destroy sctp socket call is made before a locking
call, the socket is removed without being properly locked - and leaving itself exposed to net processes. Therefore, an
attacker with network service privileges could potentially escalate their kernel
privileges to root.

This vulnerability was caused by a forgotten check the in the Linux kernel's quota mechanism. 
The function was failing to validating the quota block number, 
so the function was trying to use a value above the maximum alowed. 
The risk this vulnerability posed was a denial of service attack.

A flaw was found in the Linux kernel in the netfilter subsystem, where a local
attacker may cause a denial of service attack because the tables file lack a
full memory barrier upon the assignment of a new table value. This could lead to 
a null pointer dereference during replacement of the table.

This CVE is a vulnerability in how the kernel interacts with sockets during device 
setup. This vulnerability allows local attackers to have the ability to incorrectly 
use dynamic memory during program operations. This would then allow local attackers
to cause a denial of service attack against the machine or possibly elevate their
privileges.

A key linux feature is the KVM, the Kernel Virtual Machine, which allows you to create
an entire virtual machine including a virtual CPU. Included in the VCPU is a LAPIC otherwise 
know as a Local Advanced Interrupt Controller. An interupt controller is a program that allows 
interupt requests to be sent to the VCPU which allow the VCPU to interupt whatever current program
it is running to run a different program, including the construction of multiprocessor systems.

The vulnerbility is introduced when attempting to free the memory allocated for the LAPIC and the VCPU.
The VCPU sometimes will fail to correctly handle memory errors when being constructed, so the program will never create the LAPIC, so since
the LAPIC wasn't created, when the system attepts to free the LAPIC, this causes an error, leading to the kernal crashing, and
to someone with special user priveleges being able to cause a denial of service.

Hosts send data to a USB HID (Human Interface Devices) using HID reports. By sending a maliciously crafted HID report, a heap overflow vulnerability in the HID driver for the Logitech Unifying receivers could disclose data and allow writes to the kernel heap.

A function for testing a USB disconnect routine failed to free up a chunk of | memory space that had been reserved by it before finishing execution. This can lead to a | system crash down the road, and a malicious actor who figures out how to trigger the function | could use it to cause a Denial of Service for a Linux-based system.

Filesystems can have access control lists (ACL), which set permissions for a 
directory or file. When this list is not present and a Linux command is not
used to set default permissions, this gives the opportunity for incorrect 
permissions to be set. This can lead to elevation of privilege.

An IO subsystem in the kernel had a vulnerability that allowed a user to skip the check for if a given input was too large. A large number could be input and would roll over to a negative number. When that number was used to write to a buffer, there could be a heap overflow, allowing arbitrary code execution.

A function in the media section of the linux kernel fails to initialize a data structure before using it which would allow a local attacker with read access to the /dev/media0 folder to expose kernel memory bytes

This vulnerability was caused by spelling a variable name wrong,
Due to this mistake, the kernel's ccp_run_aes_gcm_cmd() function errored out which resulted in a memory leak.
The risk this vulnerability caused was a denial of service attack.

A file inside the Linux kernel verifies whether or not a program is allowed to run.
The file allows the program to make use of pointers in places where it
should have been using scalars instead. This can lead to pointer leaks (which is when the
reference to a place in memory is lost and thus cannot be freed or changed)
and arbitrary code execution. Scalars aren't as prone to this issue because they are usually controlled
and stored in a fixed memory location. Since pointers point to a specific address in memory and have
direct access to memory addresses, they can be manipulated to change data outside of
their intended memory boundaries.

The Linux kernel has an implementation of an encryption algorithm
called "Salsa20". Salsa20 was created by Daniel Bernstein in 2005, 
and is known for being a very efficient algorithm. Salsa20 
is a stream cipher, meaning that it encrypts a given message
bytes or bits at a time, rather than in blocks of data. In the
Linux implementation of Salsa20, the algorithm accepts a 64-byte string
which is then encrypted, and can be decrypted to retrieve the 64-byte string.
The issue with the Linux kernel's implementation of Salsa20 is that
it did not check for inputs of 0-bytes. All of the algorithm implementation
assumed that the user would provide a non-zero-byte string, so the
entire kernel would crash whenever a 0-byte string was provided. 
There are two implementations of Salsa20 in the Linux kernel, and both
implementations were vulnerable to this issue.

A flaw in the business continuity management protocol in the CAN subsystem of linux
allowed a local user to raise their priveliges within the system to root user.
The user could also corrupt memory and crash the system using this flaw.

CAN (Controller Area Network) is a networking technology which has widespread use in
automation, embedded devices, and automotive fields

Use-after-free pointer discovered in the Linux's keyboard drivers. 
This vulnerability allows an attacker to access and update a memory 
block whose initial content has been cleared. This means that this corrupted memory 
block can be used to insert malicious code into a program's source code. 

A dangling pointer caused this bug, and the fix for this bug is to correctly clear 
the memory block by setting the pointer to that memory address to NULL when it is 
no longer needed.

CVE-2014-7825 was a notable vulnerability that affected the \"perf\" subsystem
of the Linux kernel. This vulnerability allowed local and unprivileged users to
exploit the \"perf\" subsystem in a way that could cause the system to crash.
The \"perf\" subsystem in Linux is used for performance analysis and profiling of
applications running on the system. By leveraging CVE-2014-7825, an attacker
could crash the system, which could potentially result in loss of data or denial
of service.

CVE-2020-15780 allowed for injection of a malicious ACPI table via configfs.
ACPI is a form of abstraction that allows the Linux operating system to control
machine specific hardware. ACPI relies on ACPI tables for configurations. Configfs
is a filesystem-based manager of kernel objects. Using configfs, bad actors were 
able to send malicious ACPI tables that allowed them to override Linux secure boot
and bypass lockdown. Secure bott is a verification mechanism that ensures code 
launched by the computer's firmware is trusted. The lockdown feature is designed to 
protect against unauthorized modification of the kernel memory and prevent access to
security and cryptographic data. Overriding these features could allow a bad actor
to run untrusted, or malicious code, or gain access to sensitive data.

A buffer overflow, specifically an integer overflow, went unchecked in
the source code that controls the raw packet sockets. The variable was an
unsigned integer, whose value was determined by other unsigned integers,
but the variable could still overflow and corrupt memory.
An out-of-bounds write could cause a denial of service, or escalate
privileges for a user to have root user permissions. This violates
confidentiality and system integrity.

Certain flags and sockets needed to be enabled for this vulnerability
to occur, but some distributions, like Ubuntu, had these constraints
automatically enabled, so the exploit could take place from start up.

The Linux kernal had a vulnerability in its netfilter system that lead to denial of service when exploited.
This DOS was a result from a null pointer dereference, you are trying to access values
stored at a location which are actually null. This vulnerability came from the netfilter
framework provided by the Linux kernel which allows networking operations like packet
filtering, port translation, etc. Nftables store customized handlers and rules specified
by the user to filter the traffic on the network. More specifically, tabels hold chains,
e.g. input and output, which hold rules to be applied to specific inputs and outputs, 
which in turn hold expressions which the rule uses to validate the input or output. In
this case nftables offers sets of rules. This problem arose when the linux kernel was
trying to set an expression to a ruleset that has not yet been initialized and therefor
does not exist in memory. At the root of the problem was an error in order of operations.

The fix was to move the set fields initialization above the expression setup.

If a variable, k_ascii, is called several times in a row, this leads to an 
integer overflow in drivers/tty/vt/keyboard.c

Users could cause a denial of service attack with a specifically
crafted authorization key. Upon the kernel trying to check the key, it would
cause the program to panic and corrupt the stack memory, causing a denial of
service.

The Linux kernel had a vulnerability in their filesystem code that manages
fusing multiple references to a file (i.e. "inodes"). They had a situation
where they forgot to clear out a cache, which could lead to the file system
slowing way down.

The fix for this vulnerability was a single line of code, which was to simply remove the extra node from their cache.

AX.25 is a data link layer protocol for transferring data over amateur radio.
When using recvfrom() or recvmsg() to receive data from an AX.25 socket, the
socket driver prepared a struct containing the source address on the kernel
stack, then treated the struct as a memory block and copied it to userspace.
As a result, the padding bytes within the struct was also copied to userspace,
which might disclose data on the kernel stack.

A function inside the Qualcomm FastRPC drivers is not properly releasing memory
that it used throughout execution upon failure. Attackers can call this function
multiple times with failures and cause a denial of service by overexhausting the memory.

The linux kernel had a vulnerability in one of its parsing functions where it did not check
if what it was receiving was a string as desired. In the event that this function was given a file
instead of a string it would cause a Use After Free or a reference to memory after it has been freed.

The BTRFS, or "Butter FS", filesystem failed to check for malformed data in untrusted images that would be automounted. This would results in a buffer overwrite, which could then lead to arbitrary code execution.
BTRFS is the default filesystem for Fedora.

The vulnerability was found by the "bobfuzzer" project, which involved university researchers external to the team.

The fix involved some compile-time assertions as well as tracking more data and doing some extra checks as part of the automount process. The fix impacted some function signature and data that was being tracked. The fix was in a single file, but involved a lot more new code doing the checks than old code being corrected.

Multiple threads can access a bluetooth controller at the same time, which leads
to a possible race condition problem where one thread issues a command while the 
other closes the device. If the device is closed while a command is being processed, 
then the program won't function as intended.

In the linux file that implements the IP router, a relatively small hash
table was used to track IP "identities". Patient attackers could cause many
collisions, which lead to sensitive information being leaked.

The solution to this vulnerability was to switch to dynamic sizing of the hash
table. The size of the hash table is partially determined by the capabiities of
the machine, like its RAM size. For modern hosts, this will give the hash table
about two Megabytes of memory.

By causing a NULL pointer dereference in the descriptor of the USB webcam
driver, you could cause an error that would crash the system. When the value
that a pointer is trying to read is set to NULL, the system would crash, and
by manipulating that value via a USB device impersonating a USB webcam, it
could access the drivers in the stv06xx subsystem to crash the system.

In the Linux kernel 4.19 through 5.6.7 on the s390 platform, code was executing 
because of a race condition. Failure to protect a concurrent page table upgrade.
The result of this would be a crash of the software.

A flaw in processing two ICMP errors (ICMP fragment needed and ICMP redirect)
allowed an external attacker to quickly scan open UDP ports (used for remote
data transmission). This gave attackers access to IP fragments which could be 
used in DNS poisoning attacks, allowing the user to send and intercept 
messages to and from the victim without having to form a connection. 

Notes: ICMP -> Internet Control Message Protocol. ICMP messages communicate 
information about network connectivity issues back to the source of the 
transmission

UDP -> User Datagram Protocol. operates over IP to transmist datagrams 
over a network without the need for an end-to-end connection

This CVE is caused by an accidental double free on a variable. A free is when you deallocate variable
in memory. The first free is called within a function and a second free is called on the already free 
variable after the function is called. The double free can cause unwanted crashes and data corruption 
in the program.

In nested virtual machine environments, instructions are not handled from the 
bare metal hosts, and are instead emulated inside the virtual machine itself.
A flaw was discovered for Intel processors in the way that the KVM hypervisor
handled instruction emulation for an L2 hypervisor (hosted hypervisor), allowing 
an attacker to trick the L0 baremetal host (physical machine) into accessing 
sensitive L1 (baremetal hypervisor) resources that are normally inaccessible to L2
applications.

An Out of Bounds access issue occurred within a core routing protocol of the linux kernel. 
Essentially, there was a missing check on if a certain size of variable was 0 (called qrtr_hdr). 
This lack of a check allowed for a later (if) statement to read a block of block of memory that was not intended to be read. 
A 3rd party could potentially access memory outside the bounds of the protocol by figuring this lack of size checking.

The Linux kernel had a vulnerability in its filesystem, specifically btrfs, which essentially
handles the storage of files using a copy on write system and a volume manager.
They had a situation where when the user tried to delete a device using an invalid id,
the function used for finding the device by id would return a no entry error and the encapsulating
function would call strcmp on the device path and 'missing'. If the device path was not given as 
an arg to the encapsulating function, it would be calling strcmp (string compare) on a null pointer resulting in a null pointer deference
causing the system to crash.

The fix was to check if the path is null before calling strcmp

This bug is a reverting of a change made back in 2017 in a driver. This patch gave users read permission which then was reverted in the fix in June of 2020. This read permission allowed for the user to potentially be able to preform an Out Of Memory Killer (OOM) which could make the system inoperable.

The function "aac_compat_ioctl" in the "drivers/scsi/aacraid/linit.c" Linux driver does not require the normally 
needed permissions for basic IO devices. Specifically the "CAP_SYS_RAWIO" permission is not checked for before 
continuing. This allows local users to bypass intended access restrictions of IO devices like USBs via a crafted 
ioctl call. The ioctl functions are system calls used for modifying device parameters.

Issue was discovered with memory management and attempting to gain access to memory 
that has already been released in the PI futexes. Because of this an attacker can take advantage of 
this exploit to execute code and gain access to sensitive information to reallocating memory pointers.

The connection tracker for Linux's networking framework was not correctly protecting write access to three global variables for certain network environments, causing changes in one environment to be reflected in other environments.

A flaw was found in the Linux kernel. The Linux Berkely Packter Filter (BPF) subsystem,
which is mainly responsible for analyzing network traffic on a system, did not properly
consider that some subsystem variables may have been intentionally uninitialized.
This was in the name of saving memory in the BPF Type Format however this can cause a
 system crash when there is a unexpected access attempt.

The BPF Type Format BPF is a register-based virtual machine in the Linux kernel that can
execute bytecode (unreadable code to humans) in a secure, efficient, and event-driven manner.

There is a function within net/netfilter/xt_TCPMSS.c in the linux kernel with an improper handling of memory. This 
allowed remote attackers to cause a denial of service attacks and possibly other unspecified impacts. This function 
is used for setting the MSS (Maximum Segment Size) of a TCP packet. As a result a corrupted packet could modify the 
memory (use-after-free and memory corruption attacks) on a router using xt_TCPMSS.c in a iptables firewall filter. 
Improper management of memory size could allow an attacker to set memory to what they see fit or bring down the router.

A class in the Linux kernel before 5.11.12 has a use after free (meaning a pointer to a memory location is not cleared after the memory location was freed) where a guest can bypass security and access controls leading to disclosure of sensitive information, addition or modification of data, or Denial of Service (DoS).

An l2tp socket is created and used as a parameter for a inet socket.  Because of an error caused by the mismatching 
sockets, unprivileged users could escalate to kernel privileges.

An attack which exploits branch misprediction and is identified when a bad actor bypasses array bounds and attempts to leak data from a victim's memory. This vulnerability can also exploit branch misprediction making the victim run code incorrectly. Occurs in the Linux Kernal before 5.12.13 and allows an unknown BPF to read arbitrary memory locations.

Linux Kernel.nickname: Miss A Task Program Goes Blast
Linux Kernel.description:
There was a corrupted node in the timer tree that caused a tasked to be missed 
and prevented from being run. This created an issue when gathering the required functionality
which means there was a denial of service leading to the ceasing of packets being aggregated
while the system is running.

Starting at Linux kernel version 5.5.0 and beyond, the bpf verifier didn't properly
restrict the register bounds for 32-bit operations which lead to out-of-bounds reads
and would write in kernel memory.

This vulnerability involved a null pointer exception being thrown whenever an
attacker would inject a frame with 802.11a rates on a device that exclusively
supports 5GHz.

This vulnerability relates to subpar randomness being generated in lower level
linux libraries. Randomly generated characters/numbers could be predicted,
which means that the programs RNG could be predicted as well, leading to
a potential slight data exploit. This is done through Cross-Layer Attacks
which can, in laymans terms, be used to track Linux and Android devices.

The method (hw_atl_utils_fw_rpc_wait) that was the source of the vulnerability had the intended functionality 
of polling address from other ethernet devices receiving data derived from it to execute RPCs
(Remote Procedure Calls) which executes a program in a particular address of memory. It was found that someone 
could manipulate the packets being sent over a network to cause a buffer overflow when the data being sent 
exceeds available memory this could lead for the procedure from not being executed leading to a denial of
service from prevent the execution of some arbitrary function.

The Linux kernel version prior to 5.0 has a flaw where the a driver function retrieves the 
results of a variable that has already been freed. Because of this, the The MDIO bus devices
subsystem of the Linux kernel will drop a reference in an error state. An attacker can use
this vulnerability to cause a system crash, resulting in a denial of service.

This vulnerability ends up resulting in an infinite loop whenever a zero-length
biovec request is submitted. An infinite loop will drain the system's CPU and other
resources required for it to operate. If an attacker is able to get their hands on
this information, they are able to cause a denial of service to the user.

A flaw in the system allowed attackers to leak data on the XFS filesystem
otherwise not accessible to them.

A fault was found in the Linux kernel, where it wrongly
computes the access permissions of a shadow page. This issue leads to a
page fault, where, a process accesses a memory page without proper preparations.
The problem had existed long before this commit.

This entry focuses on an issue dealing with specific subsystem within the linux kernel. 
A process known as "speculative execution" (where the cpu executes code before it needs to) 
did not handle certain loads properly, mainly surrounding applications performing pointer operations. 
This allowed an attack where certain memory that unprivileged users should not have access to could access 
certain kernel memory by essentially going out-of-bounds of memory with a specific load.

An issue was found in the way memory was handled in user space to kernel communication
to a guest system running in a VM Hypervisor on a machine with Secure Boot enabled.
Aroot-like user could use the flaw to increase their privileges to that of a running kernel.

CVE-2016-6130 is a time of check time of use vulnerability. It occurred in a driver that interacts with the Linux kernel when a function requests the length of a response (time of check) and then receives that request (time of use). A malicious actor can use this time to change the length and cause information disclosure. This type of vulnerability is also commonly referred to as double-fetch.

There is an if-statement inside the cdrom_ioctl_select_disc() function where
an unsigned long argumemt is cast to an integer. However, with carefully crafted input,
when this long is casted to an int, it omits size validation of said long. Therefore,
it could cause an information leak allowing the attacker to read kernel memory.

It was discovered that hugetlbfs, the virtual filesystem used by
applications to allocate huge pages in RAM, did not flush the CPU's TLB in one
case where it was necessary. A TLB, translation lookaside buffer,
is a memory cache used to store recent translations of virtual memory 
to physical addresses. In some circumstances a local user would be able to read
and write huge pages after they are freed and reallocated to a different process.

A memory leak problem was found in the linux kernel, in the drivers for
Virtual I/O devices. This could allow an attacker with access to the
local machine could leak information about the kernel.

Due to a poorly implemented method of freeing memory in the unix_stream_recvmsg
function, any local user (even without) was able to use up all of the available
memory and crash the system that was running.

Local users can trigger a denial of service attack from a stack-based buffer overflow through 
the sg_ioctl function where user can control the size of the command being passed to the 
function. This size of the command is not checked hence the buffer overflow if it exceeds
the max size of the command.

A deadlock caused by an exit process waiting to terminate an SQPOLL thread, but that
SQPOLL thread is waiting for a signal to start. This can lead to denial of service attacks.

This vulnerability is caused by "double-checking" something that required
a lock. This means that a specific lock was being held that was used when
checking the first time, however, when a specific operation was done the 
same check would happen again. Since the lock for that check was already 
being held, a race condition occurred.

The Linux kernel had a vulnerability within the code that manages the network
sockets where a function was mishandling negative values causing denial of 
service via system crash and memory corruption.

The fix was to prevent negavative values from being entered at all by changing
the data type from u32 to int.

the n_tty_write function in the linux kernel does not properly manage tty driver access in the LECHO & !OPOST case. This will allow users to cause a race condition that will result in an overflow that can grant them priviledges to the system or cause a denial of service using long strings.

This was an issue discovered in the Linux kernel 3.16 through 5.5.6. This was an 
out-of-bounds memory access issue found in the floppy disk controller driver caused
by not checking the index for errors before assigning it.

When copying a buffer, a value was read in to use as the length of the copy. This value was not checked, and could allow for a length over the buffer side to be sent in. This vulnerability is disputed, as only internal OS calls access this method. However it could in theory one day be user facing if other changes are made, or throught anomalous OS behavior.

A leak was discovered within the linux kernal that helped determing the address of 
the isci transport protocol. when this is called, the handle of the protocol is
leaked and becomes availble to unauthorized users.

When using the KVM API, Linux used a value called internal.ndata which maps to an array. This
value can be updated by user processes, resulting in out-of-bounds writing to out of scope memory. This violates the
integrity of the system, giving access to unauthorized users as well as opening itself
to possible DOS attacks.

The dccp_rcv_state_process function in /net/dccp/input.c which listens for inputs 
freed the socket buffer when it received a DCCP_PKT_REQUEST type request for a 
packet. This socket buffer is a piece of memory which is used to accept input with 
the Datagram Congestion Control Protocol (DCCP). This socket buffer memory used for input to 
the system via DCCP can be accessed through an IPv6 address. This socket buffer would be 
freed when the DCCP received an input over IPv6. This enabled local users to gain 
unprivalaged access to the kernal's memory through accessing the freed buffer. This 
vulnerability was found using the syzkaller fuzzer.

This was a classic use-after-free issue which was caused by a race condition
in the USB core. (A race condition occurs when two threads access a shared variable
at the same time.)

Local unprivileged users can cause DOS(Denial of Service) attacks on Linux kernels NFC 
implementation using NULL pointer deference by calling getsockname() after a failed bind
call. A bind call connects a unique local port with a socket that already exists. After failing,
getsockname() would attempt to run on a failed socket connection.
An example of bind call failing: LLCP_SAP_MAX used as SAP

A memory leak flaw was found in the Linux kernel in the ccp_run_aes_gcm_cmd()
(the ccp driver for AMD Cryptographic Coprocessors) function, which allows
attackers to cause a denial of service. Basically, there was a bug that could
lead to a resource leak. So, on systems using this driver, a local user could
exploit this to cause a denial of service.

There is a discovered memory leak in a method called copy_process(), due to a 
lack of cleanup steps. The software did not sufficiently track and release
allocated memory after it has been used, which slowly consumed the remaining
memory.

A socket functon is called that frees a object that is potentially still being 
used by another socket function. This not only a use-after-free vulnerability 
but also a potential race condition which can lead to the system crashing or giving the
local user additional privelages.

As a result of improper input validation, an out-of-bounds read was discovered. There was a lack of
check for a value that shouldn't be negative in arch/arm/mach-footbridge/personal-pci.c

This vulnerability was present in one of the Linux Kernel's drivers; It was caused because 
someone forgot to free a pointer, leading to a user-after-free vulnerability. This bug could have
been exploited to corrupt data or cause a DoS on a device.

The hypervkvpd component in the Linux kernel had a security flaw that could be exploited by local users. This flaw allowed them to deceive the system by sending forged Netlink messages, pretending to be someone else. Netlink messages are a means of communication between different parts of the Linux system. Normally, the system should verify the origin of these messages. However, in the case of hypervkvpd, this crucial step is overlooked.

When using Transparent Huge pages, which is a Linux memory management system, there is a lack of support for PROT_NONE, which is used for creating memory spaces that
cannot be accessed. Because of this lack of support, attackers can use these to crash the system.

This vulnerability occured in the Linux kernel (before version 3.10, this file has
changed locations) and allowed host users of the OS to cause a denial of service due
to the vCPU (a portion of the physical CPU assigned to a virtual machine) not being 
properly initialized.

The fix involved adding checks to verify the vCPU was initialized before executing
further code.

When SCTP is enabled on a system, remote attackers can send a specially crafted packet in order to cause a NULL pointer dereference. This works by having the remote host set up two threads to attempt to connect simultaneously which triggers the Linux system to send an INIT back to the host after the initial INIT-ACK is sent. This causes the Linux host to call a method in which it tries to establish an association with a shared key that is NULL, which causes the dereference. This dereference could be utilized to casue a denial of service attack.

A function in the Linux kernel does not properly compare btree hash values. This allows local users 
to cause a denial of service attack on directories that have hash collisions.

The fs_pin struct in the Linux kernel contains two members (m_list and s_list). 
These members are usually initialized on use. However, if these members go 
unmodified, destroying or freeing them could cause the system to crash.

If an attacker used a broken or intentionally modified USB device without a bulk-in/interrupt-in endpoint, it could cause the kernel to completely crash due to a null pointer dereference and require a reboot.

A stack object in the ALSA timer has 4 bytes of padding for two of its fields,
but those bytes were being sent to the user without being initialized, allowing 
users to acces sensitive informatino through the kernel stack memory

The vulnerability is multiple memory leaks in the xfs mudule of the linux 
filesystem (fs/xfs/xfs_attr_list.c) which could enable a local user to perform 
a Denial of Service (DOS) attack. The xfs filesystem is used as a high 
performance filesystem in the linux kernal and this specific file deals with 
the logging functionality of the xfs filesystem. These memory leaks were 
caused by forgetting to free memory which was no longer being used by the 
system. A DOS attack could be performed by a local user through utilization 
of the xfs filesystem and hitting the code where the memory leaks exist by 
repeatedly inducing errors in the xfs filesystem.
It was discovered that an integer overflow existed in the perf subsystem of\nthe Linux kernel. A local attacker could use this to cause a denial of\nservice (system crash).

A driver for the usb ports in the linux kernel could cause a denial of
service on our local computer because there was a division of zero occurence
The division of zero occurence was from setting a high baud rate, which is the rate
at which information is processed from the usb port. If we set a high baud rate
the code would make a variable we are dividing another number by lower and lower
until that value reached zero, adn obviously we can't divide by zero so we got
a zero-dvision vulnerability.

An error handling flaw made it so that an attacker could create a corrupted
image that would cause a denial of service if mounted.

In the implementation of the F2FS file system within the Linux kernel, an issue arose due to improper validation of metadata when mounting an image. This could lead to a divide-by-zero error when dealing with a corrupted or malicious file system image, leading to a system crash or possibly out of bounds memory access and privilege escalation in some cases.

It was discovered that a double free error (the same location in memory
being freed twice) existed in the block layer, a subsystem of the linux 
that creates "blocks" of random access data for external devices like
CD Drives. This double free occurs when setting up a request queue. A local 
attacker could use this to cause a denial of service (system crash) or 
possibly execute arbitrary code.

A critical vulnerability has been identified in the XFS filesystem implementation within the Linux kernel. When changing the group ownership of a file or directory, XFS encounters a flaw--specifically, the group changing operation fails--that causes XFS to become partially unresponsive due to insufficient disk quota.

This vulnerability revolves around the spi_gpio_probe function. An spi gpio
is basically having multiple general purpose input and outputs(gpio) included in
one spi serial port interface, basically what manages all the ports for input
and output. These thigns can range as anything interacting with the system like a
keyboard, or mouse.

So basically the specific error here is that sometimes the action for the spi_gpio_probe
function doesn't go through, it has a failure path, with this failure path there
are memory leaks since spi_master_put() isn't called. So we have to make sure this is called
regardless of wether or not the spi_gpio_probe function is called.

Out of bounds error within linux kernal. Specifically from an empty nodelist for a memory policy (mpol_parse_str) during mount that creates an out bounds error that effects the systems availability (uptime).

It was discovered that a few media drivers in the Linux software were not properly validating USB device descriptors that provide information to the host.
This information included the version of the USB supported by the device, who made the device, etc. 
If a user with a specially constructed USB device is present, the vulnerability can be exploited. They may then use it to cause a denial-of-service (crash) or possibly to escalate privileges.

Method is called without first making a size check. This could cause a buffer
overflow leading to a denial of service attack or possibly to execute code on
a vulnerable system.

The vulnerability came about due to freeing the memory used by a pointer 
before checking to see if it is no longer being operated on. By doing this, 
it is possible to edit freed memory, leading to either a null pointer 
dereference exception, causing the system crash, resulting in a Denial of
Service attack, or the ability to execute arbitrary code, leading to
potential escalation of privileges.

A one-time memory leak at the boot was discovered. The size is negligible,
and it can't be triggered at will. They forgot to free the page held.

Two methods existed in the drivers of the kernel: write_wakeup() and
close(). In each of these methods, a pointer was used to reference a set
of data. In the write_wakeup() method, operations were done on the data,
while in the close() method, the memory was freed.

The vulnerability came about due to the fact that both of these methods could
be run at the same time. This led to a race condition where write_wakeup()
needed to finish its work before close() freed the memory. If it could not,
write_wakeup() would get a null pointer dereference exception and the system
would crash.

An issue was discovered in the Linux kernel that allows an attacker to be granted the I/O port permissions of an unrelated task. This occurs because of a mishandling that causes a loss of synchronization between the I/O bitmaps.

A driver did not perform a permission check before executing map and unmap
operations on a certain type of hard drive.
A bug was discovered with a window resize tool where a user could get a null pointer reference allowing them to get elevated access by abusing this error.

An issue was discovered in the Kernel-based virtual machines (KVM) module of the Linux Kernel
where an infinite loop would arise due to improper interaction between a resampler and edge 
triggering. This infinite loop could then be used by an attacker to consume excessive 
resources like CPU or memory.

An issue was discovered in the Linux kernel before 5.11.8 .
kernel/bpf/verifier.c has an off-by-one error which causes an integer underflow. This is
when a product calculates or uses an incorrect maximum or minimum value that is 1 more,
or 1 less, than the correct value. THis weakness leads to undefined behavior and therefore crashes.
This impacts availability.
This vulnerability can also impact the integrity.
This affects out-of-bounds speculation on pointer arithmetic, leading to side-channel attacks
that defeat Spectre mitigations and obtain sensitive information from kernel memory(buffer overflows
can be used to execute arbitrary code).
also known as CID-10d2bb2e6b1d.

Handling Xen (hardware) events in the Linux kernel runs with interrupts
disabled in a loop until no further event is pending.
Whenever an event has been accepted by the kernel, another event can
come in via the same event channel.  This can result in the event
handling loop running for an extended time if new events are coming in
at a high rate.  In extreme cases this can lead to a complete hang of
the kernel, resulting in a DoS situation of the host when dom0 is
affected.
(from openwall https://www.openwall.com/lists/oss-security/2021/01/19/6)

A vulnerability was discovered in the Linux kernel where a user would be able to access a printer port and use a deallocated pointer after free.
They would be able to corrupt memory and elevate privlages.

An issue that was seen in the 5.4 version of the Linux kernel and 5.5 of the AArch64 (ARM64) architechture, which is part of the ARM architecture family. The issue causes the top byte of the address passed to the brk() system call to be ignored. This can potentially cause the memory break to move downward instead of upwards. The result is a heap corruption. Heap corruption is when the contents of a memory location are modified thus resulting in possible memory leak.

There were resource locking issues in the floppy disk drive controller
software that allowed multiple threads to access shared resources at the same
time. A user with permissions to access the floppy device can use multiple
threads to access the device at the same time and cause a race condition
which leads to corruption all over the place. This corruption will likely
crash the system at a minimum and at worse, corrupt memory and lead to
possible privilege escalation.

Data was written past the end or before the beginning, of the memory space it was allotted
within the Linux kernel. This allowed an attacker to gain advanced privileges or cause a
Denial of Service (DoS) attack through the user name memory space. The attacker was also
able to bypass all modern security mitigations and execute their own code onto the Linux kernel.

The offical definition of the previously mentioned out of bounds memory writing vulnerability 
can be found here https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/787.html.

A local privilage escalation was discovered in the Linux kernel. The vulnerability was found in a function that facilitates communications between the virtual machine host and the guest. The ability to do so relies on the fact that a race condition or a special condition in which a bug, error, or flaw in a computer system code produces unpredictable results. This normally occurs with two threads conflicting in some way. This is created under certain circumstances when the AF_VSOCK socket is called, which leads to the opportunity to bypass key security mechanisms.

It was discovered that the rtl8188eu WiFi driver did not correctly
limit the length of SSIDs copied into scan results.  An attacker
within WiFi range could use this to cause a denial of service
(crash or memory corruption) or possibly to execute code on a
vulnerable system.

Due to a flaw in the Linux kernel, users with Haswell CPUs using certain user
space applications can crash the system due to a certain status in a record
(PEBS status/ PEBS record) being mishandled.

When working with interprocess communication, we often want messages to be
  encrypted and not readable by processes that are not involved.  To encrypt data between
  processes, a key is used.  These keys store some metadata about their sizes.  If a key
  maliciously was to claim that it was larger or smaller than it really was, there was
  previously no check to address that.  If this check was not performed, malicious keylen
  values would cause crashes in IPC messaging.
Memory was not initialized which created a two byte memory leak. The two bytes in memory have kernel data but the specific data was not identified anywhere.

A vulnerability that was created in the Linux kernel. The vulnerability happens when synic_get in arch/x86/kvm/hyper.c has a NULL pointer dereference for certain accesses to the SynIC Hyper-V, a type 1 hypervisor. A hypervisor is a piece of software that is used to manage and run virutal machines on a computer. NULL pointer dereferences occur when an application defererences a pointer that is expected to be valid, however is NULL instead. Therefore this vulnerability will cause an unintened crash or exit that can lead to a denial of service.

Exporting a subdirectory of a filesystem allowed unauthorized actors to access
other parts of the system using a command called READDIRPLUS, a function which
returns a pointer to a structure representing a directory and its attributes.

The Linux kernel had a vulnerability in which the BPF stack was not protected
